Garbage collection is a ritual that happens regularly in developed countries. In most places, it is free. But if rubbish disposal is free, people will produce too much rubbish. To solve this problem, we can charge households for the marginal cost of disposing of their waste. This will give them an incentive to throw out less and recycle more.
However, the effects of seemingly simple policies are often complex. Intricate economic models are often needed to sort them out. And sometimes, the results of this rummaging do not smell sweet.

Work can be a rewarding and fulfilling experience, but it can also be stressful and unsatisfying. To be successful in your career, you need to be able to communicate effectively, be able to work well with others, and be able to manage your time effectively. If you are not able to do these things, you will not be able to enjoy your work.
There are a number of things that can make work more fulfilling. One is to find a job that you are passionate about. Another is to make sure that you are able to use your skills and talents in your work. If you are not able to do this, you will not be able to be truly successful.
Another important factor is to have good relationships with your colleagues. If you have a good relationship with your colleagues, you will be more likely to be able to work effectively together and to be more satisfied with your work.
Finally, it is important to be able to manage your time effectively. If you are able to manage your time effectively, you will be able to get more done in less time and be more satisfied with your work.

Broadcasting is a technology that was originally used to sow seeds broadly. It is also a metaphor for optimistic modernism. It is about planned growth and the production of a rich harvest.
The question to be looked into is why a new technology that transmitted words and pictures electronically was organised in a way that made this agricultural metaphor seem adequate.
Since television is related to various two-way forms of communication, it is all the more striking that, from its very early days, it was envisaged as a centralised 'mass' medium. However, transmission to private homes from some centralised unit was simply in keeping with both socio-economic structures and the dominant ways of life in modern and modernising societies.
The pervasiveness of these structured processes and interests rendered broadcasting the 'naturally' victorious organisation of both radio and television.

The Earth is getting warmer and this is causing changes to the weather and the planet. The changes to climate will have a significant impact on plants, animals, water and soils. Humans have learned to use natural resources to their advantage, but any changes to these resources have to be taken seriously.
The problem is that we do not fully understand the processes of the climatic system and the effects of climate change. However, most people agree that the rate of change will be faster than anything we have previously experienced.
Climate change has the potential to affect the geographical locations of ecological systems, food production, water resources and human settlements. The effects of climate change are already being felt around the world, and they are likely to become more severe in the future.
The most dramatic and visible effect of global warming is the rise in sea levels. This will be caused by the thermal expansion of the ocean and the added input from melting ice. With scientists calculating that about half of the world's population live in coastal zones, the consequences of rising sea levels are potentially very severe.

It will use the gravity of Mars to return to Earth without burning any fuel. The goal is to save fuel, as fuel efficiency is a priority. Aesthetics is a theory about the beauty and meaning of art. However, the existence of art products can sometimes make it difficult to understand aesthetic theory. This is because art products exist physically and separately from human experience. They are often identified with the building, book, painting, or statue in its existence apart from human experience. This can make it difficult to understand the meaning of artistic products. Additionally, the perfection of some art products can create conventions that get in the way of fresh insight.
In order to understand the meaning of artistic products, we have to forget them for a time and have recourse to the ordinary forces and conditions of experience that we do not usually regard as aesthetic. We must arrive at the theory of art by means of a detour. For theory is concerned with understanding and insight.

It was longer, deeper and more severe than anticipated. It affected every single business in the country. Advertising people are often under pressure because they are seen as the ones who spearhead efforts to support the bottom line. They also have to deal with the problem of increasingly being asked to do their ever more difficult jobs with smaller and smaller budgets.
However, alongside these psychological and financial imperatives lies an almost paradoxical rise in the perceived importance of the marketing process. Marketing is increasingly regarded as that which it is not: a universal panacea. With approximately half of most marketing budgets being spent on advertising, there's some truth in saying that the buck then stops with the ad-people.

Summer promises us two great joys: escaping home and reading books. Books can help us to feel more at home in the world. We can relate our experiences to those described in great books written long ago or in distant lands. In the books of others, we find our own thoughts, embarrassments and dramas. Authors can locate words to depict a situation we thought ourselves alone in feeling, or can express our very own thoughts, but with a clarity and psychological accuracy we could not match.
We feel grateful to these strangers for reminding us of who we are. Through reading and travel, we escape the deadening effect of habit. Our eyes are never more open than during our first few days in a new place. Our mind is like a radar newly attuned to pick up certain objects floating through consciousness. Tiredness is a common problem in many countries. In the USA, 40 million people are affected by chronic tiredness. Some people have trouble sleeping because they are busy. A sleep researcher offered his subjects the opposite of the modern routine. He allowed them to sleep for up to 14 hours a night for a month. The subjects reached an equilibrium of eight-and-a-quarter hours of sleep.
There are some things that scientists know about human sleep. Humans sleep according to a daily cycle. They switch between four different stages of unconsciousness. When dreams occur, the brain paralyses the body except for the hands and eyelids.
However, there are also some things that scientists don't know about human sleep. It is not known why older people require less sleep. And it is not known what sleep is for.

I stood in my cowboy boots on the rocks of an old formation in the Arizona desert sand. I wore a cowboy outfit and I felt like I was a cowboy. But I wasn't. It wasn't working. I squinted into the morning sun and I had to admit, I was not at home on the range. I felt like I was flying in from Denver just after dawn. There was a cowboy in the luggage hall of Phoenix airport. He was wearing a sweat-stained I-shirt and needed a shave. He caught sight of my boots and he moved off out of the door. I thought about what I should do now. I was an ex-racing driver and I was depressed. I had a good run, made money and hung on to enough. But oh, man, I miss the heat of slipping into that graceful, elegant, shrink-wrapped super-tech machine with seven hundred horsepower behind my neck. I looked up into the soft blue morning sky. No buzzards overhead. Maybe Arizona doesn't have buzzards. But a couple of little brown birds in a saguaro cactus just in front of me were giving me advice, something like 'get away from our nest before we sing our hearts out'.

Photography has been used to record human life and activity for many years. It has allowed us to see the fleeting moment and to visualise both the vast and the minuscule. Photography has also brought us images from remote areas of the world and from distant parts of the solar system. It has been used to express the human condition and to document historical events.
Photography has also been used to promote social and political change and development. For example, photography has been used to document the cultural changes of the Italian Renaissance of the fifteenth century and to bring about the media culture that characterises our own era.

I have never started a book with more worry. If I call it a book, it is because I don't know what else to call it. I have a story to tell, but I end neither with a death or a marriage. Instead, I leave my reader in the air. This book consists of my memories of a man I knew. I have little knowledge of what happened to him between the times I saw him. I could fill in the gaps, but I have no wish to do that. I only want to set down what I know. To save embarrassment to people still living, I have changed the names of the people in the story. I have also made sure that no one should recognise them. The man I am writing about is not famous. It may be that he never will be. It may be that when his life at last comes to an end, he will leave no more trace of his sojourn on earth than a stone thrown into a river leaves on the surface of the water. Then my book, if it is read at all, will be read only for what intrinsic interest it may possess. But it may be that the way of life that he has chosen for himself and the peculiar strength and sweetness of his character may have an ever-growing influence over his fellow men so that, long after his death perhaps, it may be realised that there lived in this age a very remarkable creature. Then it will be quite clear of whom I write in this book and those who want to know at least a little about his early life may find in it something to their purpose. I became one of the smarter undergraduates, with a little house of my own, a small but powerful white car, designer clothes, and a black dress with a Paris label that I intended to wear when I took my final exams. In my last term, my father came up to see me and drove me out to a village for a meal and a chat. He asked me to do one last assignment for him, but I refused. I felt that such pressures were simply beyond my father's imagination. However, I eventually agreed to do it.

Simon Costello knew that buying the house in Pembroke Square had been a mistake. It was a possession that was only affordable by exercising strict economy. At the time, it had seemed like a sensible and desirable move. He had had a lot of successful cases and they were coming in with regularity. Lois had returned to her job at the advertising agency and had been given a rise which took her salary to thirty-five thousand.
The house wasn't really suitable for a family and they needed more room. All these things could have been achieved in a suburb or in a less fashionable part of London, but Lois was ambitious for more than additional space. The overcrowded tube journey had become an unproductive thirty minutes of brooding on present discontents. He remembered his grandfather's house in Hampstead and the smell of dinner from the kitchen.
The job was important to Lois and important to them both. The house, the au pair, their whole standard of living depended on two salaries. And now what they were precariously achieving could be destroyed by that self-righteous, interfering Venetia.

I chose this place to live because I thought I would find anonymity. But people in the shops soon start to recognise me. The roses in my garden were loved once, but they are gone now. I usually stay inside, but tonight, I am watching the swifts flying. I have cut back rosemary and lemon balm to make a space for a chair. It is a narrow London garden, where plants must grow tall or sprawling to survive.
My upstairs neighbour, Jaz, is leaning out of the window. She is a writer. I have a copy of her latest manuscript. She is asking me about my plans for the holidays. I am going to Stonebridge. I have asked her if she would feed the cats. She has agreed.
We are talking and I have a feeling that I should give her some advice. I tell her to write about nice people. She is not happy with my advice. She thinks I am being prissy. But I don't mind. I have my own life. I go out sometimes and fly home again, sitting on the tube with my nose in a book.

Heritage gives people a sense of connection to the past. It helps us understand and interpret our individual and national futures. It is also important for our well-being. Heritage can be found in many things, such as customs, material culture, stories, and places.
Museums are important for preserving heritage. They make collections accessible to the widest possible community. Museums exist to facilitate an encounter with authenticity. They present items that actually existed and had meaning at some historical time.
Architecture and environment are also important for preserving heritage. Change in our towns comes with such speed and on such a scale that most of us are affected by it in some way. If there is a psychological need for preservation, it is part of the planners job to take account of it.

Einstein was a famous scientist who developed some important theories about time, space, and matter. He made a big contribution to science by looking again at the nature of the fundamentals. His theories are famous for being difficult to understand.
Einstein's theories were part of a big change in scientific thinking. Physicists and mathematicians were trying to create a new, more rational description of the universe. Einstein made his contributions by looking again at the nature of the fundamentals.
Young Readers Throughout our childhoods, we sometimes thought that prize-winning books were boring. Our father would give us books as gifts, and sometimes he would put a book in amongst our Christmas and birthday presents. We didn't like most of his offerings, but he did expose us to some shorter works of decent fiction and, just once, to a well-known anthology of verse.
Language is a mysterious and fascinating subject. It is difficult to understand how language developed and evolved. However, there are some interesting theories about the origin and evolution of language.

Writing reviews is a skilled and multi-faceted job. It is one thing to write a short review for a newspaper, and quite another to write a long review for an international journal. The reviewer needs to think about the probable audience, the length of the review, and the other things they need to know. They also need to be able to write prose that intelligent people can understand and enjoy.
However, reviewing is not a full-time job. It is something you can only do well enough if you are also doing something else well enough.

Ralph unlocked his flat door and entered the dark hall. He felt a sense of ownership when he returned home alone at the end of the day. His flat was like a space where he could focus and be himself. He had grown impatient with its inability to be transformed. There was a puddle of letters and a red eye of the answering machine that sometimes gathered by the door. He was grateful that his windows hadn't been smashed. From his office on the Holloway Road, Ralph often looked forward to his solitary evenings at home. He would read or listen to music as the night deepened outside. He felt powerless and unable to find his own worth. He had tried to improve himself but had found that he was only able to survive. He had attended his only interview and had been offered a job. He was relieved to have pulled off twenty minutes of pleasant conversation with his boss.

I was going to witness goat racing on Easter Monday in Buccoo Village. There was a lot of people and things around me, but I managed to get a good spot. The racecourse was not very big, but it was still fun to watch. The day was ending, and I was feeling tired. There was nowhere to stop or camp, and the weather was cold. We couldn't see any villages or huts. But we did see some waves and the moonlight. We were tired, but we were happy.

There are some activities that take a long time. If you are late for a meeting, you can hurry. But if you are impatient and add the oil too quickly, the mayonnaise curdles. If you start tugging with frustration on a tangled fishing line, the knot just becomes tighter. The mind also works at different speeds. Some of its functions are performed at lightning speeds; others take seconds, minutes, hours, days or even years to complete their course. Some can be speeded up - we can become quicker at solving crossword puzzles or doing mental arithmetic. But others cannot be rushed, and if they are, then they will break down, like the mayonnaise, or get tangled up, like the fishing line.
There are also other ways of knowing that are slower than thought. These ways are often less purposeful and clear-cut, more playful, leisurely or dreamy. In this mode, we are ruminating or mulling things over; being contemplative or meditative. Perched on a seaside rock, lost in the sound and the motion of the surf, or hovering just on the brink of sleep or waking, we are in a different mental mode from the one we find ourselves in as we plan a meal or dictate a letter.

I have been welcomed warmly to a sociable and well-provisioned place. There are a lot of people living there, but I don't know them well. My school French is not very good, but I can just communicate. I miss the nuances and my phrasebook is useless. There is no problem for me in this, but there was a problem of self-confidence. I was worried about mealtimes and I would hang back. I still grin inanely or panic when people talk to me. I suspect the cause of this occasional depression is because I've lost the social predominance which my own gift of the gab has always afforded me.
One day, I met a person named Elliot. He was a young author like me and he didn't notice me. But I became aware that he regarded me with a warmer feeling after I had some success as a playwright. I received a note from him asking me to lunch and I thought he was trying me out. From then on, I began to see him more frequently.
The film director Alfred Hitchcock always said that he didn't care about the subject matter of his films or the acting, but he did care about the photography and the soundtrack. He believed that people are aroused by pure film, irrespective of their cultural background. Therefore, if a picture is designed correctly, the Japanese audience should scream at the same moment as the Indian audience.

Many things have changed in astronomy over the past 50 years. There were not many charts and catalogues, and telescopes were limited. Today, there are many more charts and telescopes. Computers have made it easier to analyze observations and publish results. All this makes it a good time for amateur astronomy.
But there has also been a loss. Now you have to travel farther to find a sky that is comparable to the sky in urban areas 50 years ago. The daytime skies are now plagued by aircraft condensation trails which can last for hours. This makes it difficult to see the sun and stars.
In the new economy, there is too much choice. There are too many things to do, too many options, and too many opportunities. This can be stressful and tiring. People are searching for 'simplexity' - the simple things that give meaning in an increasingly complex world.
McAndrews Hotel is a family tradition. We spend a fortnight there every summer. It is a special place where people can relax and enjoy themselves. We have our own group of people who come to McAndrews Hotel every year. We are old-fashioned and a little snobbish, but we respect each other's privacy.

Othello The transfer to London from Stratford of an exceptional production of Shakespeare's play Othello allows me to make amends for an unfair review that I wrote when the show opened last spring. The play is very well-acted and there are some memorable scenes. One scene is where Cassio's games get out of hand and another scene is where Iago loses control. The pace and tension throughout the play are terrific. Do not miss this production.
Lake Vostok In the heart of Antarctica, there is a lake named Lake Vostok. It is a hidden expanse of freshwater that lies beneath nearly 4 kilometres of ice. The water has been isolated from air and sunlight for up to 25 million years. Scientists are excited to probe the lake's depths and discover what strange organisms live there.
Scientists There was an interesting thing on the radio last week. Scientists are debating why they want to be scientists. Some scientists think it's because of the desire to understand everything from the atom to the black hole. But other scientists think it's because of the desire to know why we want to know all of this in the first place. Scientists are also debating whether science is a tool or a way to explain why we want to know all of this.

There is something satisfying about our relationship with food. You can make a delicious soup by throwing a few vegetables and herbs into water. Cooking is also an offering and a gesture of care and love. Sharing food is rich in symbolism and takes place around tables at celebrations.
This morning, Alistair had a lot of paperwork to deal with. He had a lot of tax forms and other paperwork. He also had a lot of books and journals. He knew that his girlfriend, Mallory, would be on time for their appointment. She was as compulsive about time as she was about neatness.
Karen created her own story, her own mythology, a mythology of difference and strength. In her story, there was a moment when she was hit in the eye by a golf club. But she was saved and she knew that she was saved for some purpose.
Miss Fogerty was excited and saddened by the scene she had just witnessed. She was excited to be the first to know something of note, but she was also saddened by the doctor's condition. She remembered with gratitude his concern for her annual bouts of laryngitis.

Joanna MacGregor is a concert pianist who has a busy schedule. She has added the task of writing books for young children learning the piano. Even though she is very busy, she still finds time to help young children learn the piano.
One day, Joanna gave a concert for kids. There was a young boy who was not impressed by her performance. He asked her to play "Match of the Day." Joanna was surprised, but she agreed to play. She played the song and the boy was happy.
Joanna is passionate about helping young children learn the piano. She believes that everyone should be able to learn to play the piano, regardless of their ability. She has written her own elementary piano tutor for children. The book is colorful and easy to follow. It includes accompaniments in a variety of styles for teacher - or parent - to play beneath a child's line.
Joanna's advice for learning the piano is to practice regularly and to have fun. She also believes that children should be allowed to improvise and to play at both ends of the keyboard.

Writing and reading are two enjoyable activities. Dr Johnson believed that writing without effort is generally read without pleasure. Good writing takes time and effort. Looking back at my handwritten school essays, I was surprised at how few crossings-out they contained. Today, I would have rewritten them five times over. The slowness of the hand disciplined the brain and made the writing more careful. The computer leads to sloppiness. Most writers using word processors find the time spent correcting early drafts more or less equates with the time originally spent on handwritten text.
Books and electronic text are two different ways to read. Reading anything lengthy on a screen is such a miserable experience that most people don't do it. What is new is not so much the branchings of electronic text as that computers don't invite the joined-up thinking of reading anything in its entirety.

You don't take sugar, do you? The secretary shouted this as a fact. She had been making coffee for many months. She forgot to make it because he wasn't supposed to be there. But nowadays he was always there. He had discovered that if he stayed away, people would invite him to do more things. She gave him a folder with a book label. The book was about history. He didn't want to see the synopsis because he had already read it. The book was not very well-written. It was like a lost conviction. The author had been given a large advance. But he didn't write much. The author was difficult to deal with. He was like a general with a lot of equipment but not enough troops. He was also very grumpy. Ten years later, he could scarcely be depended upon to turn up for his own funeral.

In England, breakfast is an important meal according to health experts. In the past, breakfast was not as common in England. There are some references to people having breakfast in the middle of the night or before starting their journey. But most people did not have breakfast unless they were wealthy or royalty. However, in the sixteenth century, breakfast became more common. This was because there was more food available. Also, people started working earlier, so they needed to have breakfast to give them energy.

When a photographer takes a photograph, he or she chooses visual information that is determined by his or her skills, personal views and experience. The photographer's choice of visual information affects the style, content and expression of a photograph. It also affects how the image is perceived and responded to by the viewer.
Sport has taught me personal discipline and determination, but it can also teach you the benefits of working as one of a team. It's very much like life - you can succeed as an individual, but you must never forget there are others around you.
Some experiences etch themselves so sharply on our memory that they form islands of clarity in our recollection. For me, such a momentous occasion took place one night in California many years ago, when I lay awake listening to the beautiful sounds of a bird singing. The bird had me convinced that I was being treated to an ad lib performance of the most breathtaking improvisational acrobatics.

Love them, fear them, worship them, human culture has always had a lot to say about birds. Birds are important to us because they are part of our culture and our evolution. They carry a huge amount of cultural baggage and are also indicators of ecological quality.
In the past, birds were used to tell us about the weather and our future. They were also seen as symbols of love and magic. Today, birds are still important to us for all of these reasons. They are also important because they are barometers of environmental change.
We can learn a lot from birds. They teach us about ourselves and about the world. They are engaging in ways we still find hard to fathom, let alone articulate. The stories we tell about birds are ways of interpreting what birds are telling us.

Maps are used to show the relationships of points and features on the Earth's surface. They are determined by distance and direction. In the past, distance was often measured in units of time, but such measurements gave more information about the relative ease of crossing the local terrains than about actual distance. Direction is also an important element of maps. The traveller's main concern was 'Where do I go from here?' and 'How far away is it?', so accurate representation of direction was not of primary importance. Written itineraries for a long time rivalled maps. Today, certain types of maps, such as those showing railway systems, may make little attempt to show true directions. Landmarks along a route were at first indicated by signs. The history of cartography is largely that of the increase in the accuracy with which distance and direction are determined and the comprehensiveness of the map content.

Tim Rice was ushered into a young man's drawing room, which was like an oasis of cultured sanity. There was a large collection of records and a stereo record player in the room. The young man's name was Andrew Lloyd Webber. He had won a scholarship to Oxford University to read history. He had a lot of talent and was determined to become a composer. Tim was also ambitious and wanted to be a pop star. He had a dream of becoming famous and making money. One day, Andrew suggested a new ambition for Tim. He wanted Tim to become a lyricist. Tim agreed to give it a go. He wrote some lyrics and gave them to Andrew. They worked together to write a musical. The musical was about the life of Dr. Thomas Barnardo. It was a worthy story, but not one that truly fired Tim's imagination. Tim was inspired by Andrew's talent and determination. He knew that he had changed careers.

Language is a powerful tool that humans use to communicate and express themselves. It is an instinct that people have, like spiders spinning webs. Climate and weather are also important factors that affect the lives of animals and plants. They can be very powerful forces that can change the landscape. Coffee is a popular drink that people often enjoy. Making coffee is an art and a science that requires time and practice.

Art on TV and Metals
There are not many programmes on television that can show the pleasure and complexity of looking at paintings and sculptures. A good example of what goes wrong can be seen in Robert Hughes's eight-part survey of American art, American Visions. Hughes is a critic you can trust. He has a personality that commands attention and he has been given nearly eight hours in which to introduce British audiences to a school of art that British galleries have totally ignored.
Dealing in Metals
For 20 years, I worked as an international metals dealer and gained something of a reputation as a speculator. Metals are regulated far less than other markets. With a bit of luck, a willingness to take a risk and a good understanding of how the market works, it's possible to make a lot of money. Risk-taking is part and parcel of the industry.
Abaco
Abaco and its off-shore cays are part of the 700 islands of the Bahamas. Each island has its own personality and something to offer. To get anywhere in the islands and cays of Abaco, you need a boat. There are plenty of boats to rent if you prefer to go under your own steam. Sailing is the most popular mode of transport here. Abaco is nicknamed 'The Sailing Capital of the World' for good reason.

The Bamboo Bike Club offers a course where you can build your own bike. It's a fun and rewarding experience. You'll learn how to select bamboo for strength, form strong joints, and assemble the frame. You can also customize your bike with different colors and accessories.
The course is held in Hackney Wick, east London, and it's perfect for engineers and anyone else who wants to learn how to build a bike. You'll need to bring your own tools and materials, but the club provides everything else you need to complete the course.
The cost of the course is less than PS500, and it includes a custom-designed frame, a fun weekend of bike-building, and all the tools and materials you need.

Self-help books and autobiographies are popular genres of books. There are many reasons why people read self-help books and autobiographies. Some people read self-help books to learn new skills or to improve their lives. Others read autobiographies to learn about themselves or to be inspired.
There are also a lot of reasons why writers write self-help books and autobiographies. Some writers write to help others, while others write to make money. Still others write to express themselves or to share their experiences.
Today's greatest scientific essayist is Stephen Jay Gould. He has written many popular books about science. Gould believes that science is a civilisation of its own. He also believes that only scientists can make a good job of presenting science.

There is a chill in the air at Cannons Gym, a popular lunch-time spot for workers in the City of London. To deal with the hot weather, the fitness centre has turned on the air-conditioning. It feels like somewhere in the Arctic at quiet times. Many air-conditioned buildings could use other methods of cooling. They could take advantage of daylight and natural ventilation and have thicker walls that absorb less heat during the day and radiate it away at night.
Sundials are instruments used to measure time according to the position of the sun. They were once a vital time-keeping device, but now they are mostly used as garden ornaments. There is a renewed interest in sundials because they are romantic and intriguing objects that remind us of our place in the cosmos.
My image of china-painting stemmed from a visit to an arts and crafts exhibition where I saw ladies demonstrating how to paint flowers on a teacup. The spectacle was riveting because each stroke formed a perfect petal or leaf. I wondered what kind of people would have the courage to enrol on a course in china-painting. In fact, the atmosphere turned out to be far from intimidating. The students were all there to have fun and not even the tutor wanted to paint petals on teacups with the robotic rapidity I had remembered.

The Wrong Country Uncle booked a package holiday for Keith and Dawne in Venice. But something went wrong and they ended up in Switzerland. They were given a room in the Edelweiss Hotel. The receptionist was friendly and offered them many things to do. But when they realized that they were in the wrong country, they became alarmed. They spoke to the receptionist and she explained that there was a mistake. They were meant to be in Venice. But she couldn't alter the booking. They were disappointed but they decided to make the best of their situation. They spent their time exploring Switzerland.

Ernest Shackleton was a famous explorer who lived in the 20th century. He was known for his bravery and leadership. People in Britain know who Shackleton was and what he did. America has only just discovered him. There are many things that people can learn from Shackleton's story.
One of the most important things is that you need to be prepared for anything. Shackleton was always prepared for the worst. He had a lot of supplies and he planned for every eventuality. He also knew that you need to be patient and optimistic. If you are patient and optimistic, you can overcome any challenge.
Another important thing that Shackleton taught us is that you need to be adaptable. If things don't go according to plan, you need to be able to change your plans. Shackleton was able to adapt to many different situations. He was able to change his plans when he needed to. He was also able to be flexible and willing to let go of things that were not working.
Shackleton's story is a reminder that we can all learn from his bravery and leadership. He was a man of great courage and determination. He was a man who was willing to risk his own safety to save others. He was a man who was always prepared for anything.

In the forests of Madagascar, there lives a primate called the aye-aye. The aye-aye is like a woodpecker. It can bore through wood and probe cavities beneath the surface to find insect larvae. The aye-aye uses its incisor teeth to gnaw its way in and its narrow, elongated third finger to probe and scoop. Scientists have discovered that the aye-aye can find insects by tapping the surface of the wood and listening for reverberations. When searching for food, the aye-aye taps the surface of the wood with its middle finger and brings its exceptionally large ears forward, focusing them at a point in front of its nose. The theory that the aye-aye takes the place of woodpeckers in the woodpecker-free forests of Madagascar is an attractive one.

Most of us have photographs of our grandparents, but not many of us know what their lives were like. We often intend to write things down, but never get round to it. We may leave videos rather than photographs, but the images will remain two-dimensional. Hannah Renier has come up with an answer: she writes other people's autobiographies. The idea came to her when she talked to members of her family and realised how much of the past that was part of her own life was disappearing.
Each book involves up to 30 hours of taped interviews which Ms Renier uses as the basis to write the life story. The final content is as good as its subject. The book costs nearly PS3,000, with extra copies at PS25 each.

The University Museum of Classical Archaeology has a collection of casts of Greek and Roman sculpture. The sculptures are replicas cast from the originals. The museum is housed in a purpose-built gallery with excellent natural light. The advantages of plaster casts are many. They allow groups of sculptures to be viewed together as originally intended. Nearly all the most celebrated works of Greek and Roman sculpture can be viewed in one afternoon.
The Sedgwick Museum of Geology has a collection of fossil animals, plants, rocks and minerals. The museum also houses Britain's oldest intact geological collection. The collection is arranged by geological age so that the major changes in life on Earth can be traced through time.
The Cambridge University Collection of Air Photographs has a large collection of air photographs. The photographs are of considerable general interest as a detailed, year-by-year record of the landscape.
The Cambridge Medieval Brass Rubbing Centre has a unique collection of brass rubbing plates. The plates are used to create wall hangings. The centre has made it possible to preserve the originals and still make brass rubbing an accessible pastime to all.

Marlowe's epic play, Tamburlaine the Great, is a thrilling night of the year. It is a long play, but it is worth seeing. The acting is excellent, and the staging is impressive.
There are also several other plays that are worth seeing this season. One play is called Dreams from a Summer House. It is a delightful new musical. Another play is called The Merry Wives of Windsor. It is a farcical comedy. And finally, there is The Voysey Inheritance. It is a major Granville Barker revival.
If you are looking for a night out at the theatre, you should definitely see one of these plays.

Emma and her friends are playing a holiday game when they find out that one of their customers is her Uncle Jim. He is trying to manipulate her affection for him and alienate her from her friends. When Emma finds her life in danger, things take a dark and compelling turn.
Two teenagers, Jack and Rill, join forces to investigate a train accident that happened in 1915. They find out that their relatives were involved in the accident.
Mary Dyer doesn't fit into her family or male-dominated culture. She loves her father's racing pigeons and knows enough to carry on managing the loft and winning prizes.
Robert Westall uses the viewpoint of a mature woman for this chilling story of rural prejudice and persecution. Rose feels just as dismayed by the methodical ruthlessness of her teenage son.

Science flying in the face of gravity. Journalist Tom Mumford joined students using weightlessness to test their theories. It looked like just another plane from the outside. The pilot told his young passengers that it was built in 1964, a Boeing KC-135 refuelling tanker. The students were in for the flight of their lives. Inside, it had become a long white tunnel. There were almost no windows, but it was eerily illuminated by lights along the padded walls. Most of the seats had been ripped out, apart from a few at the back, where the pale-faced, budding scientists took their places. The flight was smooth and the students were excited. They floated aimlessly and danced in the air. It was an unforgettable experience for everyone.

I planted trees in New Zealand. I had a lot of winters there. I also planted trees with my family. We bought a small plot of land and planted trees. It was a lot of work, but it was also very satisfying. I enjoy hard physical work. The trees are now 20 years old and in good fettle. I feel a strong connection to New Zealand.

Six years ago, I turned my dairy farm in Somerset into an 'open farm' and have established a reputation for looking after orphaned animals. One day, I found three small grey badger cubs. They were like velvet and had milky-coloured eyes. I took them into the farmhouse kitchen and installed them beside the stove for warmth. The cubs were healthy but cold and whimpering. After defleaing them, I fed them every four hours. Within a week, they had progressed to drinking from a bottle and were moving around.
The cubs were playful and would chase each other's tails. I also saw odder badgers in our field. We built a sett for the badgers to move into. The cubs finally moved into their new home. Now, I see the cubs only occasionally, but they still rush up to say hello before they go dashing off into the night.

In the past, there was a scientist named Sir Edmund Halley who lived in the 17th century. He was known for his discovery of the comet that bears his name. One of his greatest accomplishments was to chart the variations of the compass. These variations are now known as declination. Without declination, sailors were unable to correct their compasses and navigate the oceans.
Halley was one of only two men in the land at that time who were paid to conduct scientific research. He set sail for the Cape Verde Islands to chart declination. The trip was quickly aborted because of crew insubordination, but Halley returned to the seas a second time. He traveled to Rio de Janeiro, South Georgia, Newfoundland, and England. From these travels, Halley published a chart that showed the variations of the compass.
Dr. Clark, a researcher at the British Geological Survey, is planning to commemorate the three-hundredth anniversary of Halley's trip. He plans to retrace the route of the Paramore and make measurements that Halley made. The data collected should help to refine the existing mathematical model of Earth's magnetic field.

Peacocks that live in Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire, UK, have beautiful trains that they show off to the hens. The peacocks' trains are like a mystery that has puzzled scientists for a long time. Darwin believed that living creatures came to be the way they are by evolution, and that the principal mechanism of evolution was natural selection. But Wallace thought that the peacocks' trains were not just for show, but also for survival.
Now, scientists are trying to find out if the peacocks with the showiest trains are also 'better' in other ways. They have found that the females really do like the showiest males. The males with the most eye-spots on their trains attract the most mates. But whether the males with the best trains are also 'better' in other ways remains to be pinned down.
There is also a final twist to this story. If a female chooses a male with a slightly better tail than the rest, her sons and daughters will inherit their father's tail and their mother's predilection for long tails. This is called 'Fisher's Runaway'.

The best boat design should combine old and new. Tom Cunliffe says that. He designed his own boat, 'The Westerman', which is at the Summer Boat Show in London this week. The boat has a lot of new technology, but it also has some traditional features. It is a beautiful boat, and it is very seaworthy.
My own boat is not as big or as fancy as The Westerman, but it is still a good boat. It is made of wood, and it is very strong. I have owned my boat for many years, and I have never had any problems with it.
Boats need to be looked after, but they can also be very rewarding. If you are thinking about buying a boat, I would recommend that you do your research and find a boat that is right for you.

D. Cliveden is a majestic country home that offers a variety of health and beauty treatments, a well-equipped gym, and stunning gardens. The atmosphere is luxurious and welcoming.
E. Springs Hydro is a modern and purpose-built health farm that offers a variety of treatments, including aromatherapy massage and carrot cake. The atmosphere is calm and relaxing.

In the past few million years, humans and chimpanzees have not had much time to develop differences. We are still more than 98% identical to chimps. Our physical capacity for making art and anything else we consider uniquely human must be due to a small number of genes.
Modern studies of animal behaviour have shown that many similarities exist between humans and animals. For example, tools are used not only by humans but also by wild chimpanzees and sea otters. Monkeys also have a simple one, with separate warning sounds for 'leopard', 'eagle' and 'snake'.
If human art sprang from a unique genetic endowment, it's strange that our ancestors dispensed with it for at least the first 6.9 million of the 7 million years since they diverged from chimps. The earliest art forms may well have been wood carvings or body painting. But if they were, we wouldn't know it, because those materials don't get preserved.
There are some differences between human art and animal activities. Human art is non-utilitarian, it's made for aesthetic pleasure and it's transmitted by learning rather than by genes. But these differences don't seem to be fatal. Human art and ape paintings serve no narrow utilitarian functions; they were produced not for material regard but only for the painter's satisfaction.

The Taklamakan Desert is a very dangerous place in western China. Charles Blackmore crossed it and lived to tell the tale. There are very few big adventures left and very few heroes. Children's stories used to specialize in them. Now you no longer find such people in fiction, let alone in real life.
Charles Blackmore led an expedition across the Taklamakan Desert. The team was composed of four Britons, an American photographer, four Chinese, 30 camels and six camel handlers. The expedition was difficult and dangerous. They suffered from dysentery, extreme heat and thirst. But they managed to find water and complete their journey.
Blackmore felt proud of his accomplishment. He felt that he had achieved something special. He also felt grateful for his family and their support. He knew that he had found peace.

Life was getting out of hand. Susan Harr decided to unplug her gadgets and rediscover the joys of manual labour. Everyone loves technology. It makes life easier and leaves us with more time to do other things. However, a recent unhappy experience with her malfunctioning word processor has confirmed a suspicion that gadgets are often not worth the expense or the trouble. Are we as dependent on technology as we imagine? Susan has come to believe that we could not do without it, but she also thinks that we could save a lot of money by doing without electric lights.

The cabinet-maker Charles Hurst makes furniture. He is very busy and has a lot of work. He has been a cabinet-maker for ten years and has built up a very nice reputation for himself. His order book is always full for several months in advance.
Hurst is passionate about his craft and takes pride in making beautifully crafted furniture. He is also critical of shoddy, mass-produced furniture and craftsmen who churn out second-rate pieces.
If you need a decent cupboard or table, bookcase or kitchen units, Hurst is your man. You can find a furniture-maker in your countryside, but finding a cabinet-maker who prides himself on making beautifully crafted furniture with clean, simple lines is less easy.

Three theories about sleep. People spend a third of their lives asleep. It seems certain that sleep has a vital function. However, what that function might be is still in debate. Scientists are not in agreement about why we sleep so much. There seem to be three main theories. The most popular theory says that sleep is mainly for the health of our body. It claims that we sleep in order to maintain the health of our body. A second theory says that sleep is for learning. This theory holds that sleep allows us to process the information that we acquire during the day. A third theory says that sleep is for energy. This theory says that we need periods of sleep in order to have enough energy for the coming day.

Someone who behaves in a way that is different from others is called eccentric. Eccentricity is the assertion of our individuality. It is like having two forces pushing against each other inside of us. One force is called individualism and the other force is conformity. Most of us tend to conform to the majority. We feel a need to be accepted and loved. If we do something that is different from what others expect, we may be seen as eccentric. However, if we do something that is natural and unique to us, we are not necessarily eccentric. The most important ingredient of eccentricity is its naturalness.

We invited four naturalists to tell us about their favorite wildlife books. Each naturalist chose a book that was important to them for different reasons.
Geoffrey Lean's book is about environmental issues. It is a well-written book that explains the importance of environmental protection.
Linda Bennett's book is about animal communication. It is a visually appealing book that teaches you about the different ways animals communicate.
Lee Durrell's book is about conservation. It is a moving book that inspires you to protect the natural world.
Bruce Pearson's book is about ornithology. It is a comprehensive book that teaches you about birds and birdwatching.

DO REVIEWS SELL BOOKS? We asked five publishers about the effect of book reviews on their sales. They said that reviews are very important for publishers. They said that reviews help to sell books. But they also said that reviews are not the only factor that affects sales. Other factors include the book's content, the book's price, and the book's availability.

The making of weathervanes is an ancient craft that has been going on for centuries. Today, the craft is still very much alive in the workshop that Graham Smith has set up. He is one of the few people in the country who make hand-cut weathervanes. Graham's designs are individually created and tailored to the specific requirements of his customers. He can produce a unique personalised item. A lot of his customers are women buying presents for their husbands. They want a distinctive gift that represents the man's business or leisure interests. Graham has perfected over 100 original designs. He works to very fine detail, always seeking approval for the design of the silhouette from the customer before proceeding with the hand-cutting.

The Horse Whisperer was a popular book that was published a few years ago. It was written by a British screenwriter named Nicholas Evans. The book was very successful and earned Evans a lot of money.
Evans was working on a film project called Life and Limb when it fell through. He was disappointed and worried about his finances. He decided to write a novel instead of working on the film. He spent a lot of time researching and writing the novel.
The novel was eventually published and it was a big success. It sold for a lot of money and Evans was able to pay off his debts. He is now writing a new novel.

Young Masters Age is against Bobby Fischer as he seeks to re-establish himself in chess. Chess is more than ever a young man's game. After 20 years of self-imposed exile, Mr Bobby Fischer has returned to chess and is playing his old adversary Boris Spassky. Mr Fischer's victory in the first game was a masterpiece, simple but profound. But, as subsequent games have shown, this balding, bearded chess player is not the man of 1972. He is 49 years old, out of practice and out of shape. The game is played on a board with 64 squares. Each player has 16 pieces, including a king, queen, two rooks, two knights, two bishops and eight pawns. The game is played in turns, with each player making one move at a time. The winner is the player who captures the other player's king. The game can last up to eight hours. For the chess master, this period represents a ceaseless struggle. A lapse in concentration can mean disaster. So the adversaries are always in a state of nervous tension. The presence of the chess clock adds to the tension. The climax of the game is often a furious 'time scramble'. With minds racing and hands twitching, the masters blitz out their moves and press their clocks with a co-ordination that any athlete would admire.

Imogen Edwards-Jones interviews some new British talent, including a poet, a pop star, and a comedian.
There is a play writer named Nick Grosso who has written three critically acclaimed plays. He is currently adapting his first play, Peaches, into a screenplay. He says that the play is low-budget but could cost up to 30 quid.
Comedian Simon Pegg has written a television comedy series and has recently finished a tour with comedy star Steve Coogan. He says that comedy is not the hardest job in the world.
Ciaran McMenamin is a young actor who has gained a lot of recognition for his role in the series The Young Person's Guide To Becoming A Rock Star. He says that he is now in a position where he can pick and choose what he does.
Neil Taylor is a pop singer who has signed a three-album deal with Domino Records. He says that the record company's idea of good sales is very different to his own.
Poet and author Stephen Richards is a young writer who has won more prizes than anyone twice his age. He says that he decided not to go to university and that he became disenchanted with education later on.

In a novel, there is a character named Isabel who is an art student. She is concerned about her knobbly knees ruining her chances of finding Mr Right. Hope springs eternal for her, and it also helps other people in the story. The author writes with terrific verve and uses a lot of humor.
The novel also includes a story about a local radio station in America. Francis, a child, works for the station. The station broadcasts a variety of programs, including singers, preachers, and soap-opera heroes. The author is able to create a vivid and entertaining world through his writing.
The novel also includes a story about a second husband who gossips with his wive's first husband. The poetess writes rotten poetry and tries to get the support of the protagonist for her wrongfully imprisoned brother. The author is able to create a complex and engaging plot.

Volunteer tourism is a topic that four academic writers discuss. It can be a positive or negative experience. On the one hand, it can lead to greater international understanding, enhanced ability to solve conflicts, and growth of international social networks. On the other hand, it can be imperialist, paternalistic charity, or a self-serving quest for career and personal development.
Most significantly, volunteering can raise awareness of, and a lifelong commitment to combating, existing unequal power relations and deep-seated causes of poverty, injustice, and unsustainable development. However, volunteer tourism can also be seen as a way to bypass the democratic imperative of representative government and reduce development to individual acts of charity.
The act of volunteer tourism may involve only simple, commendable charity. However, where volunteer tourism is talked up as sustainable development and the marketing of the gap-year companies merges into development thinking, this is symptomatic of a degradation of the discourse of development.

Many people listen to the radio when they wake up in the morning. Most people also need some help to wake up. So, we have the clock radio. To pick a good one, you need to test five currently available models. The 'dual alarm function' does not allow you to be woken up by the buzzer, snooze a while and then finally be driven out of bed. The instruction booklet advises you to use this function to set two different wake-up times, one for work days and one for weekends. The inclusion of a cassette player is quite a bargain. You can fall asleep to your own soothing tapes and wake up to a day without news.
The clock has a self-power back-up so you don't have to reset it if someone unceremoniously pulls the plug out. Unfortunately, the smooth undulations and tactile buttons encouraged me to run my fingers over them as if they were keys on a piano, which proved my undoing. The light was certainly hard to position; you would never be able to read by it. The simplest and cheapest of all the models tested, this scored points with Tom Granger because it 'seemed very standard and took up little space'.

A hedgehog is a small mammal that has sharp spines on its body. Hedgehogs live in many different parts of the world, but none are native to America or Australia. Hedgehogs can roll into a tight ball when they are attacked. The number of spines a hedgehog has affects its ability to defend itself. Some desert hedgehogs have fewer spines and are more likely to run into their attacker. Hedgehogs are mostly active at night and sleep for much of the day. Some hedgehogs hibernate, but others stay awake all year round.

To excel in any sport is hard, even for men. But women have to be even tougher. Training and competition leave little time for a normal life, so sacrifices must be made. But against all the odds, women are beating prejudice and breaking records.
Here, we talk to just a few brilliant British sportswomen who are achieving their goals.
A. Jill is a skier. She says, "It's a great feeling to fly through the air and land cleanly, but it can be scary. You just get on with it. It's not easy to have a career outside skiing because we train for ten months of the year. You give up a lot of your social life and friends. But it was my choice."
B. Caroline is a cyclist. She says, "I'm well paid as a pro, and cycling has lots of potential in terms of endorsements. However, I know I'm not ugly and it worries me that people may think I've got where I'm because of how I look, not because I'm the best cyclist. So I tend to concentrate on the cycling at the moment, rather than earning money."
C. Annabel is a rower. She says, "Rowing is hard for girls to get into because very few girls' schools do it. So most don't start till they're 19 or 20 which makes it harder to succeed at an international level."
D. Ffyona is a long-distance walker. She says, "I was doing 50 miles and 21 hours each day with three hours sleep in high temperatures and walking with 15 blisters on each foot. But I got the record!"
E. Lisa is a saloon car racer. She says, "Being a woman has its disadvantages. When I get to a corner, the men think 'I've got to beat her', so I've had a lot of knocks!"
F. Alison is a triathlete. She says, "I get up at 5.30 three mornings a week to swim. I need Tuesday and Thursday mornings to catch up on my sleep. In the evening I just cycle or run. Yes, I do fall asleep at my desk sometimes!"

I was a student travelling around Europe and Morocco in a van. I found a boat-painting job on the waterfront. I spent much of my time drawing and was lucky enough to be carrying an ample sketchbook when I met Picasso. Picasso was known to be a reclusive artist. He spent most of his time shut away working high in the hills. I was surprised to find him seated at a table with his wife and companions. I nervously introduced myself and offered my sketchbook. Picasso agreed to sign my sketchbook. He inscribed his name across the top of the paper and added an exuberant linear flourish. I was delighted and thanked him. I returned to Picasso's table and drew his portrait. He gave me a generous nod and announced that it was now his turn. He outlined a bearded face below the head which had taken me so many anxious minutes to produce. I looked like a creature who had strayed from one of his more lighthearted mythological compositions. I thanked Picasso and asked him if he would be kind enough to sign the drawing. He said that he already had his signature. I was disappointed, but I still look back now and wonder at my good fortune. Meeting Picasso and receiving his attention meant an enormous amount to me.

Talking shop Ever entered a store and bought more than you intended to buy? Sometimes shops use special tricks to make you spend more money.
A. Some supermarkets put fresh produce at the front of the store or display plants to make the store look fresh. They may also have a bakery that smells like fresh bread.
B. The location of products in a store is important. Supermarkets use computerised stock-control to find out which products are most popular and put them in the most visible places.
C. Supermarkets may spread low-priced staples like bread and sugar around the store.
D. Chainstores have changed the way they present their wares. They use fewer items and make the prices seem lower.
E. Food shoppers are more responsive to the overall size of their bill than to the prices of individual items.
F. The price of an item is important. It's also a useful device to reduce theft.
G. Lighting is important for supermarkets and chainstores.
H. Some chainstores have divided up their floors with different carpeting.
I. In-store promotion can be very effective.

Sea, Ice & Rock Mountaineer Chris Bonnington and Robin Knox-Johnston are two climbers and sailors. They have climbed and sailed many times together. One day, Chris asked Robin to join him on a trip to Greenland. They sailed and climbed together, and they built a strong friendship.
They spent a lot of time on the sea. They sailed for many hours and anchored at a beautiful place. They also climbed a mountain called the Cathedral. It was a difficult climb, but Robin was determined to do it. He went to the top of the mountain, and he felt very proud.
There was one time when Robin was not feeling well. He was sick, and Chris had to help him. Chris was worried about Robin, but he was also trying to be patient. He knew that Robin would be okay.
At the end of the trip, Chris and Robin were very close. They had built a strong friendship, and they were grateful for each other.

Apples have been with us since the beginning of time. They are grown all over the world. There are many different kinds of apples. Some apples are red, some are green, and some are yellow. Apples are often eaten with food. They can also be used to make juice, cider, and other drinks.
In the past, people used apples to make medicine. They also used apples to trade. Apples are a very important part of our history. They are a symbol of health, wealth, and prosperity.
Today, apples are still popular. They are eaten all over the world. We can all enjoy eating apples. We can also use apples to make other things. Apples are a delicious and versatile fruit.

Explore Worldwide offers a variety of adventure travel trips designed for people who want to get more out of their holiday than just a beach. The company specializes in travel to new and unusual destinations, coupled with interesting and original itineraries. Explore Worldwide has a brochure containing over 100 original adventures in more than 60 countries around the world. Most trips last from 1-4 weeks.
The company offers a variety of travel experiences, including cultural/adventure trips, wildlife safaris, ethnic encounters, easy/moderate hiking, major treks, and wilderness experiences. Explore Worldwide also offers sailtreks/seatreks and raft and river journeys.
The company's trips are designed to be within the capabilities of almost anyone who enjoys good health, is reasonably fit, and is adaptable. The majority of Explore Worldwide's trips are designed for people aged between 25 and 55. About half of the trips are couples. The rest are enterprising individuals travelling alone.

The long-distance runner Richard Nerurkar visits a high-altitude training camp in Kenya. The camp is located ten miles south of the equator and is surrounded by beautiful playing fields and dense tropical vegetation. The athletes live in cinder-block dormitories and train hard every day. They run early in the morning, do interval training at mid-morning, and run steadily in the late afternoon. The daily regime begins at six and ends at night. Running apart, life is simple and uncomplicated. The athletes eat a simple diet and have a relaxed lifestyle. By the time the runner leaves the camp, he is even more appreciative of Kenyan success.

Advertising is not doing well. It started to decline early in 1989, well before the recession really began to bite. The main problem with advertising is that it has not been able to keep up with the pace of economic change. As a result, most people do not buy most of the brands they see advertised.
Even if you visit a supermarket, you will not buy that many advertised brands. You are unlikely to buy more than a few hundred brands over a year. And most of the clothes you buy will not be advertised brands.
If you are watching TV tonight, count how many of the commercials are for brands you buy or are likely to buy in the future. For most people, the figure seems to be about one in 16 (6 per cent). So the commercials for the other 15 (94 per cent) are, on the face of it, wasted.

Solar Survivor Charles Clover ventures inside a very environmentally-friendly home in Britain. Southwell in Nottinghamshire is full of surprises. There is a cathedral and a house that is designed to be very green. The house is super-insulated and uses rainwater for washing and drinking, recycles its sewage into garden compost and heats the house with waste heat from electrical appliances and its own body heat. It is a sunny day and the windows are closed. The air is warm and the house is quiet. The Vales, who teach architecture at Nottingham University, were serious about the environment long before it hit the political agenda. They wrote a book on green architecture back in the 1970s. They designed a building which emitted no carbon dioxide. The house is cheap to build and use.

**
The camera can lie. Arthur Conan Doyle believed himself to be a rational man, a scientist even. But in 1920, he thought he was seeing scientific proof that fairies really existed. He published photographs alongside an article he wrote, acknowledging fairies as supernatural wonders. It was not until 1939 that the two ladies who took the photos admitted these were fake. They simply cut out pictures of fairies from a book and arranged them among flowers. The results are undeniably beautiful. But the simplicity of the trick undermines a basic principle of photography, that the camera cannot lie. From the moment cameras began capturing reality, that reality was being altered.

Blacksmiths have been making iron products for many years. They used to be very important because they made weapons, armour and farming tools. Now, blacksmiths make mostly decorative items. But there has been a recent revival of blacksmithing. Thanks to greater interest in decorative architecture and a less conservative approach to interior design, more people are interested in blacksmithing.
The blacksmiths craft is a bit like drawing with metal in space. It's very challenging, but it also gives a lot of satisfaction. Many blacksmiths are fascinated by iron. They love the way it looks and feels. No other base metal can give man as much visual pleasure, or a greater feeling of security.

I stopped smoking a few months ago. It was a difficult decision, but I am glad I did it. I had been smoking for a long time, and I was addicted. I had tried to quit before, but I had always failed. This time, I was determined to quit. I went to a stop-smoking session, and it was very helpful. The counsellor helped me to understand why I was smoking and to develop a plan to quit. It was not easy, but I was able to quit. I am now smoke-free, and I am feeling healthier and happier.

Dorothy Hodgkin was a British scientist who won the Nobel prize in chemistry in 1964 for her work on penicillin and vitamin B12. She also solved the structure of insulin. Hodgkin was a very successful scientist, but she also had a personal life. She was married to a historian and had three children. Her personal life is not strictly relevant to her work as a scientist, but we can all learn from her capacity to unite the disparate threads of her life into a coherent whole.

Margaret Wilkins has a special ability to find water. She can hold a forked hazel stick above the ground and detect water. She is very busy these days because there has been a lot of drought. Most of her customers are farmers with wells that have dried up. To find water, Margaret uses a map and a hazel stick. She also checks the land with her hazel stick. If she finds water, she drills a well.

**
We changed lives for a day! Have you ever dreamed about swapping lives with someone else for a day? Perhaps you think it would be more fun to do something quite different for a change. We fixed it for four people - read how it went.
A. Amanda's story I couldn't believe how dark and noisy it was at the restaurant. It was all a far cry from my home town and, to he honest, I wasn't sure I'd survive! Being a mother is definitely a busy job - but this was something else! I had just fifteen minutes to learn how to carry a tray of drinks at shoulder height with one hand. The other waitresses made it look so simple, but just as I was getting the hang of it, the drinks started to slide off the tray and crashed on to the floor, splattering cocktails everywhere.
B. Cindy's story I was feeling quite apprehensive about being a 'mum' for the day, but I was looking forward to it, too. As Amanda left to make her way to the restaurant, I had to get the two girls dressed and fed. But it was when I brought Sophie home from school that the real trouble started. They turned the settee into a trampoline and played a game which involved screaming as loudly as they possibly could.
C. Rosemary's story On the farm, I have to get up early and sleep late. It was difficult to stop myself dipping my fingers into the goodies! The process of milking the cows took an exhausting two-and-a-half hours. And Rosemary does this twice a day, starting at 6 am, seven days a week, 365 days a year!
D. Hilary's story I found it quite a lonely day. The worst aspect of the job is not being able to get away from work. The cows always have to be milked twice a day, so it's really difficult to plan any time off.

A trumpet is not just for Christmas. It is strange that many musicians, even leading ones, come from homes without music. Hakan Hardenberger is a musician who has established himself as unique among the world's trumpet-players today. He has a lot of success and plays the trumpet very well.
Hardenberger was born in Malmo, Sweden. He owes his career to the accident of a Christmas present when he was only eight. His father gave him a trumpet, and he started playing right away. He had a lot of lessons from a teacher who was also a trumpet-player.
Hardenberger has a lot of success. He has won many competitions and played in many concerts. He is known for his unique sound and his ability to communicate with people through music.

The book "New In Paperback" is a story about a group of people living on the island of Efica. The book is divided into five parts.
In the first part, the author introduces the main character, Tristan Smith, and his world. The book is also notable for its humour and the author's unique vision.
In the second part, the story introduces the character of Harriet and her family. Their lives are shattered when their son, Joe, is attacked. After the court case, both boys refuse to talk about what happened.
In the third part, the story introduces the character of Sheila and her family. Their lives are also shattered when Joe is attacked.
In the fourth part, the story introduces the character of Aurora Greenway and her companion, Rosie Sunlap. Their story is about life and loss.
In the fifth part, the story introduces the character of Logan Urquhart and his yacht, the Ardent Spirit. The story is about self-discovery and the power of experience.

Take Five Careers Rebecca Cripps meets five women who discuss their different professions. Each woman has a unique job and a unique set of challenges and rewards.
A. The Brain Surgeon
B. The Senior Designer
C. The Chauffeur
D. The Landscape Gardener
E. The Civil Engineer
These women work in a variety of fields, including surgery, design, driving, and landscaping. They all have to deal with their own set of challenges and rewards, but they are all passionate about their work.

Six people talk about their typical working day. Each person has a different job and responsibilities.
A. Credit Card Executive: Manages all customer development programmes for regular credit card users. Has to keep in touch with existing card users, acquire new ones and build relationships with partner companies.
B. Record Company Executive: Deals with demo tapes, letters, invoices and meetings about campaigns or projects for a particular artist.
C. Sales Director: Opens the post, looks through the diary and waits for clients. Loves taking people round the showrooms and selling furniture.
