Career Power Get the leading edge - motivate yourself to take full control at work.
A good leader is one who inspires, motivates, and encourages others. To be a good leader, you need to be able to speak clearly and articulately, have confidence in your abilities, and be able to set goals and achieve them.
You can also benefit from improving your leadership skills if you are a manager. If you are a manager, you need to be able to keep your company running smoothly and motivate your employees.
To be a good leader, you need to be able to delegate and motivate others, organise and chastise, praise and raise, and be visible and accessible to those who are important.

A film critic named Nick James reviews some recent releases. He reviews a Cold War thriller, a war movie, and a swashbuckler. The Cold War thriller is about oil riggers and navy experts trying to rescue a nuclear submarine stranded many miles beneath water. The war movie is about the battle for Guadalcanal. The swashbuckler is about a group of musketeers. The film critic finds that the story in the swashbuckler film is corny but highly watchable. He also finds that the production design and costume design in the war movie are excessively detailed.

A lawyer named Steve Martin is struggling to build a new practice. He finds himself defending his boss's wife when she is tried for her husband's murder. The trial scenes are exciting and the book is a good read.
There are also other books mentioned in the text, but they are not important to the main point of the story.

Tim Pozzi is a 34-year-old who decided to go backpacking this summer. He feels nervous about his decision because he has a lot of responsibilities and is concerned about making arrangements. He also worries about being out of place among a community of backpackers fresh out of school and university. However, he believes that travelling offers a chance to reassess and take a step back to think about your life.
There are many reasons why people are choosing to travel in their late twenties and thirties. Some people are unhappy with their jobs, while others simply want to experience new things. There are also a number of factors that make it easier to travel at this age, such as the flexibility of the workforce and the availability of career-break policies.
Whether you're young or old, travelling can be a rewarding experience. It can give you the chance to see new places, meet new people, and learn new things. It can also help you to find out what you want and what you don't want in life.

I had a long break from journalism and I felt out of touch with the changes brought about by technology. I was able to transform my family home into an efficient workplace. I had a lot of problems learning to use computers, but I managed to learn the basic skills I needed. I have become an organised worker and I can now work from home. I have also been able to start freelancing for a magazine.

The Tartan Museum is a modern museum in Scotland. It has a lot of interesting objects. The museum is located in Edinburgh, a historic city. The museum building is very impressive. It has a huge, yellow sandstone tower and cheese-wedge buildings.
The museum has a lot of exhibitions. There are displays about the history of Scotland. There are also displays about the country's culture and people. The museum has a lot of visitors. People can learn a lot about Scotland from the museum.
The museum also has a Discovery Centre. The Discovery Centre is for children. It has a lot of interactive games and activities. The museum is a popular place for children to visit.

The end of print may take some time. It's a pleasant word and a calming concept. Change may frighten some and challenge others. But transition means going surely and sweetly from somewhere present to somewhere future.
The latest print circulation figures show that sales are plummeting while visits to the same papers' websites keep on soaring. Sales in the West dropped back but Asia more than made up the difference.
The latest National Readership Survey figures show that nearly 5,000,000 people aged between 15 and 35 follow the main national dailies.
Of course, this huge difference isn’t good news for newspaper companies. Maintaining both an active website and an active print edition is difficult, complex and expensive.

People are the most interesting subjects to photograph. A photograph with someone in it is usually more compelling than the same shot without the human interest. To photograph people well, you have to be conscious of actions, gestures and expressions. You also need to consider the background and the environment. If you can find a good spot and position the camera correctly, you can take great pictures of people.

Sarah Janson is an artist who creates illusions of reality through her paintings. She is not interested in being known as a creator or genius artist. Instead, she focuses on the work itself. Janson has been painting for sixteen years and has a lot of experience in illustration and decorating. She is also known for her observational skills and fascination with detail.
Janson's paintings are often inspired by architecture and made for architectural settings. There is one painting that gives the illusion that you can step into two further rooms. Another painting is based on the facade of a Venetian palazzo.
Trompe-l'oeil has to be clever and personal to the client. Janson believes that it must also draw you in and hold you. She also likes to interact with clients and get inside their imaginations.

In the workplace, there are new rules for success. These rules are based on social skills and personal qualities, such as initiative and empathy, adaptability and persuasiveness. These skills are commonly referred to as emotional intelligence.
Emotional intelligence is the ability to monitor and regulate one's own and others' feelings, and to use feelings to guide thought and action. It includes basic elements such as self-awareness, self-regulation, motivation, empathy and adeptness in social relationships.
More and more businesses are seeing that encouraging emotional intelligence skills is a key component of management philosophy. If you have strong emotional intelligence skills, you are more likely to be successful in your job.
There are many ways to improve your emotional intelligence skills. You can learn about them and practice them. By developing your emotional intelligence skills, you can improve your overall performance and success in the workplace.

**
Should the media earn money from content they don't own? Although it is easier to capture newsworthy events with digital cameras and camera phones, social media has revolutionised citizen photography. With news regularly breaking on social networks, some journalists are now turning to them as sources of images as fast-moving events occur. Unfortunately, some reporters have published user-generated content (UGC) without permission. Despite official guidance that images posted on social media can be used without permission if there are exceptional circumstances or strong public interest, debate continues about whether this is ethical. With research indicating that a large number of people would film or photograph a news event, it is clear that UGC has a major role to play in the future of the media. However, if the media is to prevent its relationship with the public from souring, steps must be taken to ensure that people are properly rewarded for their work and that permission is always sought.

Ancient Chinese medicine, also known as acupuncture, is a traditional Chinese system of medicine that has been used for centuries. It is used to treat many different conditions, but acupuncture's role in treating pain has been the most popular.
Acupuncture points are located on meridians, which are lines that run through the body. When the flow of energy (Qi) is disrupted, the body becomes unbalanced and can become sick. To treat imbalances, acupuncturists use fine needles inserted into the skin.
Acupuncture can be used to treat a variety of pain conditions, including back pain, arthritis, headaches, and migraines. It is also used to treat other conditions, such as menstrual pain and facial nerve pain.
If you are considering acupuncture for pain relief, it is important to find a qualified acupuncturist. You should also discuss your condition with your doctor to see if acupuncture is right for you.

P. D. James, a best-selling crime writer, is known for her complex and brilliant imagination. She is a headmistress of a girls' school and has written many detective stories. Her books are read avidly by millions all over the world.
P.D. James was born in Oxford and grew up mainly in Cambridge. She met her husband there and had two daughters. Her life has been hard, even tragic at times. She worked full-time in administration for the National Health Service and made good use of her organizational skills.
Writing detective stories is a way for P.D. James to bring order out of disorder. She believes that the solution of a crime confirms the sanctity of life, even if that life is unlovable.

The pen is mightier than the psychoanalyst. Handwriting analysis, or graphology, is accepted as a genuine science in many countries. It can be used to indicate certain illnesses, such as heart disease and cancer, and can reveal psychological states and emotional disturbances.
Handwriting can also be used for vocational guidance and as an adjunct to interviews. Many big companies now employ graphologists to analyse the handwriting of potential candidates for key jobs.
However, there is little hard evidence to support the claims made about handwriting analysis. Some psychiatrists are highly critical of them. They say, handwriting is a product of education, artistic ability and the type of writing taught - and has no other significance.

Is your office working ok? Fresh air and comfortable chairs are the key to a happy, healthy workforce, according to a new survey. We went to four different offices to find out how healthy and happy they were as working environments. We had an expert panel of a building health consultant, an ergonomist, and an occupational psychologist. Here are their verdicts.
Office A is a small office with a lot of natural light. The employees are happy and healthy, but the office is not very comfortable. Office B is a comfortable office with good air quality and plenty of space. However, the office is a bit impersonal and unstimulating. Office C is a busy office with a lot of activity. The employees are well-served by technology, but the office is not very comfortable. Office D is a dusty office with a lot of problems. The employees are stressed and driven by deadlines, but the office is not very comfortable.

Chewing gum is a popular fashion accessory in the United States. Americans chew 12 million sticks of gum a day. Gum is made from a natural substance called chicle, which is obtained from the sapodilla tree. The ancient Greeks and American colonists chewed gum-like resin. Today, chewing gum is mostly made synthetically. It is often used to reduce tooth decay. Gum manufacturers say that chewing gum can increase your salivary flow.

The Ghanerao Hotel in India and the Hermitage Hotel in New Zealand are two charming hotels. The Ghanerao Hotel is located in a small rural village and offers a peaceful atmosphere. The Hermitage Hotel is situated in the most beautiful countryside and provides a luxurious experience.
The Paradis Hotel on Mauritius is another beautiful hotel. It is isolated on its own peninsula and offers a private beach. The Ladera Hotel in St. Lucia has a dramatic setting and provides a colonial-style atmosphere. The Splendid Hotel in Istanbul is a historic hotel with a unique charm.
The Fairview Hotel in Kenya is a comfortable and affordable hotel. It is perfect for travellers who want to relax and enjoy the beautiful surroundings. The Hotel Splendido in Portofinto is a historic hotel with a glamorous past. It offers a luxurious atmosphere and stunning views of the Mediterranean Sea.

The hotel inspector Sue Brown judges hotels for a living. One day, she was inspecting the Globe Hotel. Things were not going well. The receptionist was reciting room rates over the phone to a potential guest, but she was not paying attention to Sue. Sue was not happy with the service at the hotel. She said that the hotel was not what she had expected. There was a problem with the plumbing and the room was not clean. Sue also suggested that the hotel staff should not usher guests into the room so readily.
The hotel manager was worried about Sue's report. He was afraid that the hotel would lose its red stars. But Sue reassured him that she would not recommend that the hotel be stripped of its red stars. However, she did say that another inspector would be back to make sure that everything was put right.

Seven Up Mountaineer Doug Scott shares his experience of conquering the highest peak on each continent, the Seven Summits. My quest to climb the Seven Summits came late in life. I climbed the Seven Summits in the order I completed them.
A. Mt. Everest, Asia (8,848m)
I was in a snow cave below the summit when I started talking to my feet. The cold was getting into my feet and I remembered other climbers who had lost fingers and toes from frostbite.
B. Mt. McKinley, North America (6,194m)
This mountain is regarded as the most treacherous in the world. We followed a new route and spent a lot of time on the ridge.
C. Kilimanjaro, Africa (5,89Sm)
We got lost in the dense jungles and ran out of water. We found a rock pool and spent the night there.
D. Aconcagua, South America (6,960m)
The route up Aconcagua is easy. We went across the north ridges and joined the large number of people walking along the path.
E. Vinson Massif, Antarctica (4,897m)
We travelled to the South Pole and climbed Vinson Massif. The weather was very cold and windy.
F. Elbrus, Europe (5,633m)
We walked to the refuge and crossed open slopes. We reached the summit and returned to the refuge.
G. Carstensz Pyramid, Australasia (4,883m)
We climbed Carstensz Pyramid and reached the summit. I was given a standing ovation on this, my seventh summit. Mission accomplished!

Style Merchants Style is a company that provides information about the latest fashion trends. Jo Foley, Ned Ingham, Sally Quail, Lily Grimson, and Peter Little are some of the designers who work for Style Merchants Style.
Ned Ingham designs wedding dresses. He says that people should avoid traditional, stiff dresses and frilly looks in favour of simpler styles. He has been drawing and designing wedding dresses since he was a schoolboy.
Sally Quail is a jeweller. She designed her own engagement ring and set up her own business. Her pieces are sought out by many stars of stage and screen.
Lily Grimson is a handbag designer. She has had two of her creations selected for a major design exhibition. Her bags are handmade in the UK and are full of glamour.
Peter Little is a hairdresser. He has been taking his scissors to some of the world's top heads for over 20 years. He says that most women want real-looking hair and a style they can manage at home.
Penny Pratt is a florist. She has no floristry qualifications and gave up her job as a teacher in order to do 'something different'. Her simple, yet incredibly modern, creations have begun to capture every design prize in the flower business.

The Merrion Hotel is a five-star hotel that has recently opened in Dublin. It is a new hotel that has been created using four large eighteenth-century houses. The hotel has a lot of technology, including a computer system that can deal with return clients and a system that controls room temperature. The hotel also has a lot of amenities, such as a swimming pool, gym, conference rooms, bars, and restaurants.
The Merrion Hotel is likely to be successful because of its technology, its amenities, and its highly capable staff.

Artist Susan Shepherd is known for her flower paintings. She has a large garden that is full of her favourite flowers, mostly tulips and poppies. Some of the plants are unruly and seed themselves all over the garden. There is a harmony of colour, shape and structure in the flower borders that line the paved path. Much of this is due to the previous owners who were keen gardeners. Susan prefers to focus on detailed studies of individual plants rather than on the garden as a whole. More usually, she picks them and then takes them up to her studio. Her busiest time of year is spring and early summer, when the tulips and poppies are out. She has a come-what-may attitude to the garden, rather like an affectionate aunt who is quite happy for children to run about undisciplined.

No title. Many trees in the Brackham area were blown down in a terrible storm that March. The town itself lost two great lime trees from the former market square. The disappearance of such prominent features had changed the appearance of the town centre entirely. Chief Inspector Douglas Pelham, head of the local police force, was annoyed by the change. He was sick with bronchitis and couldn't concentrate on his work. His wife, Molly, tried to persuade him to go to the doctor, but he refused. He was too busy working. When he finally gave in and went to the doctor, he was prescribed antibiotics and went home. The loss of the trees had made a permanent difference to the appearance of the living-room. The room seemed cruelly bright and the worn furnishings were exposed in all their shabbiness.

We lived in a valley for a long time. One day, we noticed that the hills around us were dangerous. The snow started to fall and it covered the land. The snow and wind were inconvenient but they did not really trouble us greatly. The river was the biggest threat to us. It was flowing very fast and it was dangerous. The snow started to melt and the river became even fuller. One day, the river overflowed and it was like Niagara Falls. The water surged over the dam and poured into the stream below. We were scared but fortunately, the dam held and the waters began to subside. We can enjoy the big clouds and the powerful river, thanks to the dam.

Film critic Mark Adams has been writing articles about films for a newspaper called The Front Page for the last ten years. He had a few different jobs before he became a film critic. He met Tom Seaton, the first arts editor of The Front Page, who also wrote for radio and television. Tom hired Mark, but he was not primarily a journalist. He had a lot of ideas for how to improve the newspaper. One of his ideas was that a team of critics should take care of the art forms that didn't require specialised knowledge. There would be a weekly lunch at which the critics would make their choices from the artistic material that Tom had decided they should cover. Mark feels that his job is to put forward an argument, not to be 'right' about a movie.

Why would a schoolgirl want to swim 1500m, cycle 40km and then run 1Okm? Because it's fun. A teenager with a taste for endurance wanted: Sports-mad training partner for triathlete, preferably female. The triathlon promises to be one of the most popular Olympic sports. Recently it has drawn huge crowds fascinated (and horrified) by athletes swimming 1500m, cycling 40km, then running 1Okm without stopping.
Melanie entered her first triathlon at 14. She won the junior section - but then she was the only junior taking part. She was determined to do well and she worked very hard. But she did not give up and is determined that she never will.
Melanie has tried other events. She has had a go at the triathlon 'sprint', for example, where you only have to swim 750m, cycle 20km and run 5km. She wants to enter even tougher events than the triathlon.

The Collectors Amanda Roy writes about the things she collects and why people enjoy collecting. Collecting is a world of passion, envy and enthusiasm. If you enter this world, remember one thing: you must fall in love with an object before you collect it. People have been collecting things since the beginning of time. Some people collect stones and seashells just for the beauty of their forms and colours. Others collect flowers, pottery or paintings. If you want to start a collection, you do not have to be rich or powerful. You can start with small items like tulip bulbs or china cups. You can also collect toys or other items that you enjoy. As small objects become popular, they begin to rise in price. The toys of the 1950s are now positively an investment.

Four people talk about their jobs. Lisa is an exhibition organiser at the Science Museum. She is responsible for putting together temporary exhibitions. She has to plan and design the exhibition, and promote it. She also has to make sure the public can understand the thinking behind the exhibition.
Janet is a teacher of London taxi drivers. She teaches students how to make journeys in London. She gives them directions and tells them which routes to take.
Sarah is a marine conservationist. She lives by the coast and works from home. She helps people learn about the life underneath the sea.
Chris is a map and atlas publisher. He has to make sure that the books that are published are accurate and up-to-date. He also has to deal with a lot of paperwork.

No title. We always go to Ireland in June. Every year, the four of us have spent the first fortnight of the month at Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim. It's a large house by the sea, not far from the village of Ardbeag. The Malseeds bought the house and have added to it. They have a lot of flowers in the hall. In winter, when no one much comes to Glencorn Lodge, Mrs. Malseed sees to little details like that. In the morning, we'd walk along the sands to Ardbeag and have coffee in the hotel there. In the afternoon, we'd drive somewhere. I knew all that because over the years this kind of pattern had developed.

Sarah Sutherland-Pilch is a chalet girl who works in Val d'Isere, France. She makes beds and delicious dinners for visitors who come to ski and stay in the chalets. Sarah graduated from Oxford Brookes University last summer. Being a chalet girl isn't a career, but it's an enjoyable way to spend a year or two before settling down.
Sarah gets up early and prepares breakfast for the guests. She also clears up and makes the afternoon tea. After that, she goes skiing. She returns to the chalet in time to prepare dinner and takes a shower. Sometimes she will chat with the guests, other times they are content to be left alone.
At the end of the day, Sarah meets her friends and goes out to the bar. Sometimes she is tired and has an early night, other times she enjoys a drink and chat with the guests. On Sundays, she has to work earlier than usual to prepare breakfast for guests who are leaving. After that, she cleans the place and prepares tea for the new guests. Sometimes she takes guests down to the ski shop and gets a lift back to the chalet. It is soon time for dinner duty again and perhaps a drink later.

Miss Rita Cohen, a young girl, came to Seymour's factory one day. She was small and had a lot of hair. She was interested in learning about leather. She asked many questions about the process of making gloves. Seymour was happy to help her. He showed her how to make gloves and she learned a lot.

Chris Arnot asked four people with dream jobs if they're as wonderful as they seem. There are two main types of dream jobs: ones that involve travel and ones that involve creativity.
A. Raquel Graham is a personal assistant to a pop star. She loves her job and gets on well with her boss, but she can't stand flying.
B. David Brown is a golf caddy. He prefers the golf to his accounting job, but he doesn't earn much money.
C. Martin Fern is the editor of the 'Food and Drink' pages of a daily newspaper. He loves to cook and he thinks that expensive restaurants are worth it for people who can afford them.
D. Dick Prince is a children's writer. He loves to write and he gets a lot of letters from his fans.

In the yard, there was an old brick building and a lot of sawdust. There was a lot of sawdust covering that part of the yard. That afternoon, Michael was bored and he climbed up the old building. He sat on the roof and looked out across the lake. Suddenly, he said, "I dare you to jump down," and he jumped off the roof. He lay on the sawdust and laughed. His friends followed him up and jumped down one by one. They all lay on the sawdust pile telling jokes. After a while, Michael was tired and he decided to go home. He was late for dinner and his stepmother was angry. She said, "You're big enough by this time surely to be able to get home in time for dinner. But if you won't come home, you'd better try staying in tonight."

You are not happy with your job, but you don't know how to change. If you need help, you can go to a careers adviser. They will ask you to write a brief history of yourself and then sit through a number of tests known as 'psychometrics'. After that, they will give you a summary of the findings and suggest various careers.
Last March, Donna Laney lost her job and decided to go to Career Analysts for help. She was told that she had a gift for design and that she should go into that field. Donna is now working as a Public Relations officer.
If you are feeling stuck in your job and don't know what to do, you might want to consider going to a careers adviser. However, you should be aware that not everyone who goes to a careers adviser gets the advice they need.

If you walk into W. Lloyd Jerome's dental surgery in the centre of Glasgow, you'll see bright modern paintings on the wall and a fashionable blue couch. Jerome says that many people are afraid to go to the dentist. To counteract this, he has tried to create an environment where people are not afraid. He has introduced new relaxation techniques, such as virtual-reality headsets and a pleasant smell in the surgery. The surgery smells more like a perfume shop than a dentist's. Today there is the smell of orange. The quality of the treatment is of course the most important thing. For example, Jerome uses a special instrument which sprays warm water on the teeth to clean them, rather than scraping them.

Chocolate, which has its origins in South America, is a popular treat in many countries. People in Britain spend a lot of money on chocolate at Easter and Christmas. The cacao plant was first cultivated by the Aztec, Toltec and Mayan civilisations of Central America thousands of years ago. The fruit of the cacao tree contains seeds that can be used to make chocolate. In English-speaking countries, cacao beans are often called cocoa beans. The Aztecs used cocoa beans as money and to make a drink called xocoatl. The Spanish found the drink more palatable mixed with cinnamon and sugar. Chocolate houses were set up in Europe's capital cities where people gathered to drink chocolate. Until the last century, chocolate was made from solid blocks of chocolate which had to be melted down in hot water. But in 1826, a Dutch inventor named CJ van Houten invented chocolate powder. The age of the chocolate bar as we know it began in 1847 when a Bristol company, Fry and Sons, combined cocoa butter with pure chocolate liquor and sugar to produce a solid block that you could eat.

Peter Cooke is a shell artist. He has been making beautiful objects out of shells for ten years. He has a lot of ideas for things he would like to make, but he is limited by his physical abilities. Still, he has managed to produce some amazing work.
Cooke's work is different from the common shell constructions that can be found in seaside shops. He uses a lot of tiny shells and he creates intricate designs. He also uses unusual materials, such as cardboard and glue.
Cooke has traveled to many different places to collect shells. He has been to France, Thailand, Mexico, South Africa, and the Philippines. He only collects dead shells and he defends himself against people who write him letters accusing him of stripping the world's beaches.

When 15-year-old Kira Langer is not flying to wonderful locations or appearing on the covers of magazines, she is revising for her school exams. She is a very friendly, very tall, very pretty girl. All models under the age of 16 must take an adult with them whenever they work. Kira has the looks, ability and support to have a fabulous career ahead of her.

Father and son, Terence and Chris Madden, have travelled from Canada to Africa to find gold. They believe their mine on the side of a Welsh mountain could contain a lot of gold. After ten years of digging, they are convinced that they are close to a vein of gold. They have spent a lot of time getting permission for their work, taking samples of the earth, and removing old cars and rubbish. Now they need more money to finish their work. They are running short of money and will have to convince a backer to put money into the project.
The Welsh gold industry has gone into decline since its height in the late 1880s. However, individual gold-diggers are returning. George Hall, another prospector, plans to drive a tunnel deep into the hill.

Rachel Mills is a scientist who studies the chemical processes happening in the sea. She teaches and does research into marine geochemistry. When she isn't teaching, she dives down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes.
The dive can last for 16 hours. If there is a problem, you can hit a panic button and the escape vessel will be released.
Last year, Rachel dived with a Russian crew. They went to a site which was a five-day sail west of the Canary Islands in the Atlantic. Here, on the ocean floor, is a huge area of underwater volcanoes.
When Rachel isn't at sea, she is in her office at the Oceanography Centre, Southampton. She loves teaching and she does it so she can get on with her research.

I was dirty, smelly, hungry and tanned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body and mind couldn't handle any more punishment. I was tired of foreign timetables, currencies and languages. I said, "Never again," as I stepped onto home ground. I said the same thing the following year and the next. All I had to do was buy one train ticket and I could spend a whole month going anywhere I wanted in Europe.
I took great pride in the fact that, in many places, all I could be bothered to see was the view from the station. We were just there to get by, and to have a good time doing so. The excitement of travel comes from the sudden reality of somewhere that was previously just a name.
Only by actually seeing Europe, by watching the changing landscapes and seeing the differences in attitudes and lifestyles, can you really have an accurate picture of the continent in your mind. Everybody knows what is there, but it is meaningless until you view it yourself. This is what makes other people's holiday photos so boring.

There is nothing more disappointing than arriving at an airport overseas and finding that your baggage has been left behind. If your luggage is not there, you may have to wear the clothes you stand up in for hours or days. Sometimes, the airline may not be able to find your luggage and you may have to wait a long time for it. The system for handling baggage at airports is complex and can be unreliable. It is important to check in well before the official time and to allow more connecting time if you are changing planes. If your luggage goes missing, you should contact the appropriate airline official in the baggage hall and complete a property irregularity report (PIR).

The kingfisher is a beautiful blue-green bird that lives near streams and rivers. It feeds on fish. The bird cuts like a laser through the scene, straight and fast. It has gone in a split second, but a trace of the image lingers. Charlie James fell in love with kingfishers at an early age. He spent a lot of time watching them. He has a lot of photographs of kingfishers.

Anne Inglis talks to five new conductors about their work. There are different challenges and rewards associated with being a conductor.
A. Anne Manson was asked to help on an opera the next season. She was nervous at first, but she was able to take the first orchestral rehearsal for Abbado.
B. Andrew Constantine won a major competition in 1991. He is finding it difficult to lose the 'competition' label.
C. Wasfi Kani loves the long practice period which is part of any opera production. She started conducting seriously in her late twenties.
D. Roger Vignoles started out as a resident musician with an opera house. He was asked to direct Handel's Agrippina from the piano at a festival.
E. Wayne Marshall was noticed by a conductor and soon found himself conducting a musical in London. He was tough with the musicians and was able to get the best result.

If you're thinking of taking children to a theme park, there are many to choose from in Britain. We asked five families to test the best. There are rides for all ages at the park. The younger children loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There are also rides for older children, such as Splash Out and the ferris wheel. After five hours, Steve and I were ready to call it a day, but the children objected because they were having such fun. The park is clean and well-organised. The staff are friendly and helpful. You need a full day to enjoy the park.

Five women talk about their experiences setting up a business in the countryside. They have different businesses, but they all enjoy being independent and having more control over their work hours.
A. Christine Hogan runs a computer-aided design business. She has a lot of customers and she can work from home.
B. Maggy Sasanow works from home as a designer of greetings cards. She has a big room upstairs and she gets work from all over the world.
C. Delia Turner runs a curtain-making business. She has seen good times and bad times, but she is still working hard.
D. Tessa Strickland runs a children's book publishing business. She enjoys being able to work when she wants to and she publishes books from all over the world.
E. Meg Rivers runs a cakes-by-post business. She started small and has grown her business to be very successful.

Meet the Watkins family. They are musicians. The sons are composers and prize-winning musicians, while Dad makes the instruments.
John and Hetty Watkins have a son named Paul. They needed to get him a cello to suit his blossoming talents. They found out that there was a school of instrument making nearby and John started taking evening classes. He made a cello for Paul and another one a bit later.
Paul is now 28 and he is a cellist. He won the string final of the BBC Young Musician of the Year competition and was appointed principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra. He has a new cello that is 304 years old.
Huw is Paul's younger brother. He is 22 and he is a pianist and composer. He has his own band and is playing at the Cheltenham Festival and the Wigmore Hall.

The National Trust is an organisation that conserves the British countryside. Gareth Roberts is a warden employed by the Trust to look after the beautiful areas it owns. To be a National Trust Warden, you need to have common sense and be good at handling people. Gareth was born and bred on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm until he married. He has come to understand more about nature conservation since he has been with the Trust. Conservation is one of the main aspects of Gareth's work. His role is to make sure jobs get finished, with as little fuss and as economically as possible.

Suzie Ellis went to meet England's netball captain, Kendra Slowinski. Kendra is captain of England's netball team. She had a typical day for the weeks leading up to the World Championships. She taught at a local school and had a training session in the local supermarket car park.
Kendra is very focused when she is playing. She doesn't see anything else except her movements and her feet. She also says that playing netball has become harder and faster.
The World Championships will be tough. There will be a lot of pressure on the England team. But Kendra is confident that they can win.
The England team are currently ranked fourth in the world. But the World Championships will be different because there's only one chance. You have to push yourself to play each day, there's no rest between games.

A child who shows outstanding musical ability may need special understanding and education. There are five music schools in Britain that provide a sympathetic environment for gifted children aged between seven and eighteen. These schools offer a range of musical activities, including individual lessons, orchestras, chamber groups, voice training, conducting and theory. Children at specialist music schools spend a lot of time on musical activities, but also have a restricted academic programme. The cost of attending a specialist music school is high, but there are scholarships and financial assistance available. There are also concerns about the pressure and stress that can be associated with sending children to boarding school at a young age. If you are considering sending your child to a specialist music school, it is important to weigh the pros and cons carefully.

Artist Susan Shepherd is known for her flower paintings. She has a large garden that is full of her favourite flowers, mostly tulips and poppies. Some of the plants are unruly and seed themselves all over the garden. There is a harmony of colour, shape and structure in the flower borders that line the paved path. Much of this is due to the previous owners who were keen gardeners. Susan prefers to focus on detailed studies of individual plants rather than on the garden as a whole. More usually, she picks them and then takes them up to her studio. Her busiest time of year is spring and early summer, when the tulips and poppies are out. She has a come-what-may attitude to the garden, rather like an affectionate aunt who is quite happy for children to run about undisciplined.

Sarah Sutherland-Pilch is a chalet girl who works in Val d'lsere, France. She has been a chalet girl for two years. She cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in the chalets.
Sarah's day begins early. She gets up at 7 a.m. and walks to the chalet. She has breakfast and prepares breakfast for the guests. After breakfast, she cleans up and makes the afternoon tea. She then goes on the slopes and skis as much as possible.
In the evening, Sarah prepares dinner and takes a shower. She does not sleep. Dinner is served at 8 p.m. and coffee is usually on the table by 10 p.m. After dinner, Sarah clears away the dinner things and fills the dishwasher. Sometimes she will stay and chat with the guests, other times they are content to be left alone.
On Sundays, Sarah has a busy day. She starts cleaning early and prepares tea for the new guests. Sometimes she takes guests down to the ski shop and gets a lift back to the chalet. It is soon time for dinner duty again and perhaps a chat with friends.

Mandie Currie, a zoo-keeper, spent the day at the office of a magazine. She went to a photo studio and to press previews before lunch. The zoo is a peaceful place, and Mandie was rushing around when she could be sitting quietly giving an animal a cuddle.
Alice Cutler, a fashion assistant, spent the day at London Zoo. She arrived in her leather boots and dark blue trousers and got a polo shirt to wear. As she stroked one of the elephants, she thought about Mandie packing up clothes.
Karen Hodson, a nurse, went on location with the television gardening programme Ground Force. She was excited about meeting the team and the presenter was really nice. One of the things she liked was the chance to be in the fresh air.
Charlie Dimmock, a landscape gardener, worked a shift at Hammersmith Hospital. He made beds and handed out tablets. He felt his job was a real waste of time compared with nursing.
Lucy Harvey, a personal trainer, spent the day with the airline Ryanair as a member of the cabin crew. She felt completely different when she put on the uniform and people stared at her.
Sonia McDermott, an air hostess, spent the day as a personal trainer in a gym. She was dreading doing this swap but was amazed at how much attention you give to one person.

On the rails, five celebrities tell Andrew Morgan their favourite memories of railway journeys. Andrea Thompson, a newsreader, fell in love with the south of France a long time ago and tries to get back there as often as she can. There's a local train from Cannes along the coast which crosses the border with Italy. It takes you past some of the most amazing seascapes.
Raj Patel, an explorer, has enjoyed so many rail journeys through the years, but if he had to pick a favourite, it would be the Nile Valley Express, which runs across the desert of northern Sudan. The one misfortune in his youth, growing up in South Africa, was missing out on a family train journey from Cape Town to the Kruger National Park.
Betty Cooper, a novelist, is indebted to one train in particular: the Blue Train, which took her and her husband on their honeymoon across France to catch a boat to Egypt.
Martin Brown, a journalist, was working on a series of articles based on a round-the-world trip and had to cross a dessert in an African country. There wasn't a road, so the only way they could continue their journey was to take what was affectionately known as the Desert Express.
Arisu Mezuki, an actress, imagines most people's favourite impressions of trains and railways are formed when they are young children, but that's not her case. She was brought up in Singapore and Cyprus, where she saw very few trains, let alone travelled on them.

If you want to get your story published, you need to do some research and practice your writing skills. You should find out which magazines use the type of writing you want to do and get hold of as many recent copies as you can. Then, familiarise yourself with the kind of stories they are buying. If you have only written one story or one article, it is not at all likely to be published. If you want to become a successful writer, you need to write a lot and keep practicing. You should also join a local writers' group or take a creative writing course.

No title. I was waiting at the Baltimore railway station for the 10.10 to Philadelphia. There were a lot of people waiting. The station was not clean and polished like it usually is. There were elderly couples and college kids. A man was walking around talking to different strangers. He was well-off. He went up to a woman sitting alone and asked her a question. He came over to me and asked me if I was travelling to Philadelphia. I said yes. He asked me if I could help him find his daughter's passport. I said no. He was stressed out. He was talking to a woman reading a book. He said he had to go get his daughter's passport. I let my eyes wander toward the two of them. The man was holding a packet. It looked to be stapled shut. I said silently, "Watch yourself, lady."

John Moore is a restaurant owner. He has a son named Gary, who is a famous TV chef. John believes that everyone has a chance in life. He was given the chance to run a restaurant, and his son Gary was given the chance to cook.
John's restaurant was in a really bad state when he heard about the opportunity. He rushed over to look at the place and it was perfect for what he had in mind. He ran the business with his wife and children. They lived over the restaurant and always put a lot of emphasis on having meals together.
Gary was a lively child. He had a lot of discipline and was always up early in the morning. He started cooking at a young age and was very successful. He went to catering college and started his own business.
John is proud of Gary's success. He has always tried to tell him that if you want something, you have to work hard for it. Gary has seen the opportunity he's been given and grabbed hold of it with both hands.

Finding a good flat in Dublin was like finding gold in the gold rush. If you knew someone who knew someone who was leaving a place, that often worked. But if you had just arrived in Dublin, there was no chance of any personal contact. You had to stay in a hostel and search.
Jo felt like she was stepping into the unknown when she got on the train to go and work there. She didn't ask herself why she was going there in the first place. She was heading off on her own.
There was a flat in Dublin that was perfect for Jo. It was near the post office where she worked and seemed too good to be true. But it was not too expensive. The flat was upstairs and there was a cheerful-looking girl coming down the stairs.
The girl was talking to Jo and said that she couldn't stand the girl who was going out. Jo went on climbing and said hello to the girl. They were going to have a mug of tea.

Dolphins are popular animals that people love to see. They are intelligent and sensitive to human emotions. They also allow us to dream of freedom. However, dolphins are facing a number of threats, including pollution, overfishing, and human disturbance.
One of the biggest threats to dolphins is pollution. Pesticides and other chemicals can build up in the bodies of dolphins and be passed on to their young. This can cause a number of health problems, including death.
Another threat to dolphins is overfishing. If fish in one area are removed by fishing, dolphins may not be able to find enough food to survive. They are also in danger of getting caught in fishermen's nets.
Finally, human disturbance is a major threat to dolphins. Noise pollution from ships and other sources can disturb dolphins in ways that we do not yet understand. This can lead to a number of problems, including death.

Getting fit is important for your mind, body and spirit. It's one of the best ways to stay healthy and happy. There are plenty of reasons why you should exercise and very few - for most of us why you shouldn't. Exercise can help you to feel better, improve your mood and make you sleep better. It can also help you to control stress and relieve certain medical conditions. If you're not sure, you should consult your doctor on what's good for you personally. Stretching is also important for improving flexibility and ease of movement. If you stretch regularly, you will be able to move more easily and feel better.

In their natural habitat, Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman, two film-makers, are often away from their home comforts for months on end. They are searching for the perfect shot. Their present habitat, the Ngorongoro Crater, has been affected by a lot of rain. They had to invest in an expensive piece of equipment to help them when their vehicles get stuck in the mud. Their partnership has created some of TV's finest wildlife films. They are often travelling to remote areas to film exotic wildlife. They have learned to set aside four months on location to gather sufficient material for each half-hour film.

Suzie Ellis went to meet England's netball captain, Kendra Slawinski. Kendra is captain of England's netball team. She had a typical day for the weeks leading up to the World Championships. She taught at a local school and had a training session in the local supermarket car park.
Kendra is very focused on her training. She said, "My whole life now is all about making sure I'm at my absolute best for the Championships." She is on a strict timetable to gain maximum fitness for them.
The World Championships will be tough. There will be a lot of pressure on the team. But Kendra is confident that they can win. She said, "You don't do all that training not to come out a winner."
Netball is also taking a far more scientific approach to fitness testing. Kendra said, "It is essential that we all think and train like world-class players."
As captain, Kendra has a strong mental attitude and leads by example. She said, "From the very beginning, my netball career has always been carefully planned." So she took the decision some time ago that this competition would be the end of it as far as playing is concerned.

Rachel Mills is a scientist who studies the chemical processes happening in the sea. She teaches and does research into marine geochemistry. She is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she isn't teaching, she dives down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes.
A dive can last for 16 hours. If there is a problem, you can hit a panic button and the escape vessel will be released. No-one has tested it yet, but it would be a very unpleasant journey.
When Rachel isn't at sea, she is in her office at the Oceanography Centre. Two thirds of her salary comes from teaching. She loves teaching, but she does it so she can get on with her research.

First impressions are often lasting ones. People form impressions about us within the first few minutes of meeting. They observe how we dress, our eye contact, our body movement and how fast or slowly we talk, our volume and tone of voice as well as our actual words.
Mary Pearce was a student who studied to be a teacher. She worked hard to earn her degree and was confident when she graduated. She applied for a job at a nearby primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. However, she didn't get the job. The Head Teacher said that if someone doesn't take the time to present their best image at an interview, what kind of teacher is she going to be?
It is important to have a professional image and to communicate clearly. If you want to do well in an interview, you should dress professionally, make good eye contact, and speak clearly and concisely. You should also be prepared to answer questions and show that you are interested in the company.

Matt Froggatt used to be an insurance agent but now runs a sheep farm. He was made redundant and decided to set up the farm. He is glad he is no longer stuck in the office but he still has a lot of work.
Ron Able white was a manager in advertising but now makes a living as an artist. He decided to take redundancy and become an artist. He is happier now and feels less stressed.
Katherine Goodison set up her own business making hats for private clients. She left her job as a lawyer because she wanted to have a better work-life balance. She is happier now and feels less stressed.
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur. He was unhappy with his job and decided to change careers. He is happier now and feels more in control of his destiny.

Four young sports stars talk about their lives. They are all dedicated to their sports. They have to make sacrifices to be successful.
Darius is a runner. He has to train hard and be disciplined. He also has to give up late-night parties.
Gabriel is a surfer. He has to cut out late-night parties and give up lie-ins. He also has to be serious and professional.
Dieter is a yacht racer. He has to be traditional and celebrate wins in great style. He also has to be careful about his health and well-being.
Tomas is a tennis player. He has to travel a lot and be serious and professional. He also has to make sacrifices in his personal life.

Young shoppers at the supermarket often want everything they see. Usually, all three of the following items are bought: the latest sugar-coated breakfast cereal, a Disney video, or a comic. Parents often struggle to manage their children's shopping demands. They feel guilty about buying and feeding their children rubbish, and they hate saying no all the time. Supermarkets could do a lot more to ease parent-child conflict.

The Merrion Hotel is a five-star hotel that has recently opened in Dublin. It is a new hotel that has been created using four large eighteenth-century houses. The hotel has a lot of technology, including a computer system that can deal with return clients and a system that controls room temperature. The hotel also has a lot of amenities, such as a swimming pool, gym, conference rooms, bars, and restaurants.
The Merrion Hotel is likely to be successful because of its technology, its amenities, and its highly capable staff.

I get my energy from doing things I enjoy. I like to dance, write, and spend time in nature. If I'm feeling bored or sad, I find that doing something creative or physical can give me energy. I also get energy from being around people who are positive and happy.
I have a lot of work to do, but I enjoy it all. If I'm feeling tired, I need a fair bit of sleep. When I get enough sleep, I feel really good. I also get energy from exercising and eating healthy.
I believe you must have an interest in and respect for what you do in life. If you do things you don't want to do, it will wear you out. You only have a certain amount of energy, so direct it into the things that are most important to you.

Ice skating has a long history. People have been skating for thousands of years. In the past, people used skates made from animal bone. Nowadays, people use skates to compete in different events. There are many different styles of skating, but the basic skills are the same for all. To skate, you need to be relaxed and have good balance. You also need to know how to fall safely. If you are new to skating, you should start by learning the basic figures. Once you have learned the basic figures, you can move on to other styles of skating. Skating is a great way to improve your balance, coordination, and overall health.

There is a young girl named Julia Gregson who is very talented at collecting medals. She has won a gold medal for gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She wants to become a physiotherapist and compete at the next Olympics.
There is also a young girl named Sarah Stokes who is very talented at show-jumping. She has won the British National Championship. She loves show-jumping events and is determined to qualify for the British young riders (under-18) team and win a gold medal at the Olympics.
There is also a young girl named Jane McShane who is very talented at chess. She is Britain's Under-14 Chess Champion. She loves playing chess and is not scared of getting big-headed.

Chris Greener was tall when he was fourteen. He is the tallest man in Britain today. Every year, more and more people are born who are tall. This does not mean that humanity is producing a new super race. We are returning to what we were like as cavemen. Our ancestors ate a wide variety of foods, including fruits, berries, and herbs. About 9,000 years ago, agriculture was invented. This has had a disastrous effect on human health and physique. Today, most people eat a diet that is based on three carbohydrate-rich plants - wheat, rice, and maize. This poor diet has had a disastrous effect on human health and physique. As a result, the average man in the US is now 179cm, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm.

Studio audiences are a common feature of television life. They are made up of people from all classes, professions and income groups. People go to studio audiences for different reasons. Some people hope to appear on television, others are curious to take a look behind the scenes, and still others just want to have fun.
When you sit in a studio audience, you feel more excited and involved with the show. You may also see live actors, which you can't see on your television at home. Going to a studio audience may not be the best way to watch television, but it can be a fun and free night of entertainment.

Bruce likes landscapes that have a human element. He went to school in England and would cycle to the village of Lastingham on Saturdays. He loved exploring the hills, valleys and old villages. He found the landscape familiar yet different and still goes back there today.
Sophia loves a miniature railway that goes from Hythe to Dungeness. The scenery is not spectacular but there is one point on the journey that she always looks forward to - when our miniature world takes a detour through back gardens.
Matthew likes the Hartland Peninsula, a remote and lovely coast. The beaches are hard to reach and scattered with rocks, so crowds are largely non-existent here. He enjoys hiking and reflecting on the majesty of the sea.
Annette's favourite place in England is the Trough of Bowland, a landscape of wide-open moorland. It's an unknown corner, empty and remote, and she likes the feeling of space.
James purchased Glenthorne, his favourite house in Britain. It's a magic, secluded, romantic house. You can't hear anything except sea, wind and birds.

We love animals. One day, my daughter found a pine snake. We decided to keep it overnight. We set up a special tank for the snake. It was pouring rain and the snake escaped. I was able to catch the snake. I sat on the floor like a snake-charmer and the snake relaxed. I eventually released the snake back into the wild.

In our fast world, letter writing is at risk of disappearing. But to me, there is something special about receiving a letter. It's the excitement of its arrival, the pleasure of seeing who it is from and the enjoyment of the contents. Letter writing has been part of my life for as long as I can remember. I started writing letters to my mother when I was young. My mother also taught me to write thank-you letters. When I left home to train as a doctor, I would write to my parents once a week. I also had penfriends from all over the world. I love the letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards. I am pleased that my children are carrying on the tradition. Like my mother before me, I insist they write their own thank-you letters.

Tens of thousands of ancient pictures carved into the rocks at one of France's most important tourist sites are being damaged. The drawings include pictures of cows with horns, cultivated fields and various gods and goddesses. But as the popularity of the site increases, the pictures are being ruined by thoughtless graffiti.
The drawings are being damaged rapidly and will not survive for future generations. People are stamping on the drawings, wearing away the rock and definition of the artwork as they do so. Some visitors even chop off parts to take home as souvenirs.
Experts are divided over the best way to preserve the drawings. Some believe that the only way to save the site is to turn the whole mountain into a 'no-go' area. Others want to let people look at the site but impose rules to prevent damage.
The main problem is financial. There is not enough money to hire enough guards to prevent visitors from damaging the drawings. There may also have to be a charge for visitors.

Once upon a time, climbers went to the mountains. Now, you can climb anywhere, indoors or out. The crowd holds its breath. High above them on the climbing wall, there is a climber named Francois. He is competing in the World Cup Climbing Championships at Birmingham's National Indoor Arena. The National Indoor Arena is famous for staging the TV show Gladiators. There is also a climbing wall at the National Indoor Arena. The climbing wall is made of bricks with special edges that climbers can hold on to. You can climb on the climbing wall all year round.

If you want to be an actor, it's a very risky career. There are a lot of actors, but not enough jobs. If you choose to become an actor, many people will tell you you're crazy. But it's a very personal choice, and only you can take responsibility for yourself and your ambition.
There are no easy ways of becoming an actor. You need to be lucky and talented. But there is also the possibility of excitement, glamour and the occasional rich reward.
If you ask actors how they have done well in the profession, they will not know. They will know certain things about themselves and aspects of their own technique and the techniques of others. But they will take nothing for granted, because they know that they are only as good as their current job.
So actors tend not to talk about their chances. They come up with ways of protecting themselves against the stress of competing for a part and the possibility of rejection.

We have a special selection of cookbooks that are perfect for beginner cooks. There are two main types of cookbooks: those that teach you the basics of cooking and those that provide delicious recipes.
The first type of cookbook is called "Delia Smith's Complete Cookery Course." It has everything you need to know to cook basic and advanced dishes. It also has hundreds of delicious recipes.
The second type of cookbook is called "The 30-Minute Cook." It has quick and easy recipes that can be made in 30 minutes or less. It also has a lot of healthy recipes.
No matter what type of cookbook you choose, you can be sure to learn new cooking skills and enjoy delicious food.

Two brothers, Dave and Norm Lagasse, are playing a game called pichenotte. It is a game of skill that is popular in Canada and the USA. The game is played on a wooden board with 12 pieces called pucks. The goal is to flick the puck into a hole in the board. The game usually lasts just two minutes.
The Lagasses have made a lot of money from selling pichenotte boards. They have sold more than 450 boards and they make $595 for each board. They have also started a business and they are making a living from the game.

The Model Village is a popular attraction. It was built by one man and his wife. The village is made of many different models. The models are made from stone, concrete, wood, and plastic. They are very detailed and accurate. The village has a lot of different buildings, including a manor house, a castle, a church, and a zoo. You can also play mini-golf in the village. To enjoy the village, you can press the buttons on the models and make them operate.

Week after week, newspapers in Britain publish pictures that can intrude into people's privacy. Sometimes, pictures of celebrities are taken without their consent. This can cause great damage to individuals in the public eye. Very few people call on the services of the Press Complaints Commission (PCC), which was set up to deal with issues of this kind. The pictures that are published in newspapers are often not in the public interest. They are often private pictures of celebrities. If a celebrity feels that their privacy has been invaded, they may complain to the PCC, but very few actually do. The PCC should take the initiative on this and other shameful attacks. It would surely lead to many decisions against newspapers. However, there are some problems with this idea. It would be difficult to decide whether or not to launch an inquiry. And if the person involved still refuses to do anything, the PCC might still proceed. There is also the embarrassment factor to consider. People may not want to be further embarrassed by an investigation. Overall, there is no easy solution to this problem.

A lot of advice is available for college leavers heading for their first job. If you are taking a real step on the career ladder and choosing a job to fit in with your ambitions, you should choose your second job very carefully. You should be aiming to stay in it for two to three years. It should show evidence of serious career planning and extend you, develop you and give you increasing responsibility. If the travel bug is biting, now is the time to pack up and go. Future potential employers will be relieved to see that you have got it out of your system and are not likely to go off again.

Confident people have learned to be confident. They have to have a skill that they have learned because they had to. Nina Hathway asked five people how they did it. A Jenny, B Michaela, C Lisa, D Barbara, and E Kim all said that to be confident, you have to believe in yourself and be willing to try new things. You also have to like yourself for what you are, not try to be what others expect. If you just get on with it and learn from any mistakes you make, you're more confident the next time round.

Paul Forster goes to a kite-flying festival in Malaysia. He spends a nervous night in the forest. He met a friend named Adnan Ali who gave him a traditional kite. The kite was made of tissue paper and split bamboo. They sat down in the shade of the trees and looked out over the festival. The festival had a lot of kites and people. The kites flew into the air like rockets. There was also a lot of music and dancing. Paul decided to stay at Baba's place. Baba was a friendly man who took care of the kitchen and the huts. Night was totally black and there was a lot of noise. In the morning, there was a beautiful view of the mountains. In the afternoon, it rained. Paul was wet through but he was still happy. He went sliding downhill and wondered how the giant butterflies avoided the enormous drops. He also thought about his car being swept away and the likelihood of drowning. Fortunately, his car was still there. No one is a stranger for long here. Back in Kota Bahru, Kelantan's capital, everyone was friendly. They asked Paul questions about his home and his age. But in the asking there was nothing but friendliness. Kelantan might be best known for its kites but Paul remembered it more for its human kindness.

What kind of shopper are you? We all go shopping, but there are different types of shopper. Do you know which kind you are? Abby Edwards asked around and found out that there are different types of shoppers. Some people are addicted to shopping, while others are reluctant or careful.
There are different reasons why people shop. Some people shop for essentials, while others shop for fun or to cheer themselves up. Some people enjoy shopping, while others don't like it at all.
If you are a shopper, what kind of shopper are you?

The Gallery is also holding a special exhibition called 'Painting in Spain during the late 18th century'. The exhibition features works by three Spanish painters of this period.
The Gallery is also pleased to announce that they have improved their restaurant service. With its new kitchens, the restaurant offers a wide choice of hot and cold dishes at reasonable prices.

For one group of children, Saturdays are special. They learn how to cook. Their lessons are popular. There is a waiting list of children who want to do the course. Parents pay a fee for the course. The children can have fun and learn how to make good food.
There is a young boy named Bill who loves his mum's cooking. He can do it better than his mum. The teachers make the children laugh. They share the food they've made.
There is also a young girl named Flora who loves cooking. She did a meal for ten friends. Her mum suggested she take up a hobby. Flora was happy staying at home. She wasn't too keen at first. But she's glad she decided to come.
Their teacher, Philippe, says, 'It's great fun.' The children pay attention and remember things better than adults. Although the kitchen isn't always as tidy when they're cooking, they have a lot of fun.

The Outdoor Centre offers a variety of activities for people of all ages. There are fees for using the centre's facilities, which are paid at the main office. The centre is not a private club; it is an organisation that provides outdoor sport and recreation facilities for everyone.
Group visitors are asked to inform the centre in advance of their planned visit. There are courses for beginners and advanced learners in windsurfing, sailing, climbing, surfing, and archery. The centre also has a play park for children.
Safety is a top priority at the Outdoor Centre. All staff are trained in First Aid and qualified to teach the activities on offer. Children are only allowed to participate in activities that are suitable for their age and physical abilities.

Millions of people enjoy a hobby that is both interesting and fun. Collecting stamps is a hobby that can grow and grow. You can start your collection easily because stamps are everywhere. You can get stamps from postcards, letters, and cards. If you want to start collecting seriously, you can join the Stamp Collectors' Club. As a member, you can order new stamps and receive them in different ways. You can also get a Starter Pack which contains 100 stamps and a box to keep them in. To join the Club, simply complete the application form and send your membership fee.

Money is like a gram or a kilometre. You can exchange money for something else. A five pound note can buy a book, a big bag of sweets, or a couple of cinema tickets. But the note itself is just a piece of paper which costs almost nothing to make. Thousands of years ago, people didn't have money as we know it. There were no banks or even shops. In those days, people exchanged things that they had. This was an exchange arranged between two people, each of whom had something that the other wanted. But in time, most societies invented their own 'currencies' so that people could exchange more. Today, everyone uses a national currency.

You must include the application form with your story. The closing date is 30 July. Please send your story and application form to the address below.

The First Woman Scientist Hypatia was born in Alexandria, in Egypt, in 370 A.D. She was the only woman scientist to have a place in the history books for many centuries. Hypatia's father was a teacher, and he made sure his daughter had the best education available. After studying in Athens and Rome, Hypatia returned to Alexandria where she began teaching mathematics. She soon became famous for her knowledge of new ideas. We have no copies of her books, but we know that she wrote several important mathematical works. Hypatia was also interested in technology and invented several scientific tools to help with her work. At the time, many rulers were afraid of science, and anyone connected with it was in danger. One day in March 415, Hypatia was attacked in the street and killed.

The fares are PS10.00 for adults, PS5.00 for children, and PS25.00 for families. You can see historic trains at Wansford Station. There is also a nature reserve and a miniature railway in Nene Park. Grass is probably the most successful living plant in the world. There are many different types of grasses and they are found in every region on the earth. Grasslands support a wide range of animal life, from small insects and birds to big animals like cows and lions. All of them depend on grass in one way or another. Grass recovers very quickly after it is cut or damaged. Unlike other plants, the new leaves grow from below the soil, not from the top of the plant. That is why large families of animals are able to live together in one area. As soon as they have eaten all the grass there, a fresh meal is always available because the plants start to grow again.

The Young Achiever of the Year Kal Kaur Rai has always been interested in fashion. She has won the title of Young Achiever of the Year at the Asian Business Awards. Ever since she was a child, she has drawn clothes and designed patterns. She never told her parents that she wanted to turn her hobby into a career. She thought they expected her to go into a more established business, so she went to university to do a management degree. After university, she moved to London and worked in an advertising agency. She had to attend industry events but couldn't afford the designer clothes she liked. She started making skirts and tops for herself. When her friends saw her clothes, they asked her to make things for them. She then found a small shop in London willing to take her designs on a sale-or- return basis. They were very popular and nothing came back. This encouraged her to leave her advertising job, take out a loan and begin her own womenswear label. Her clothes are now on sale in over 70 stores and her business has an income of over PS500,000. Her clothes appear in fashion magazines, she designs for pop stars and she has just gained public recognition by winning this award. Her business has come a long way and she knows she is extremely lucky.

The Sunningdale Hotel was built in 1913 and opened by Princess Louise. It has provided excellent service for people from all over the world. Many people have stayed at the Sunningdale Hotel. The hotel is on one of the main roads leading to the town centre. It is about 20 minutes by bus from the centre of town and buses to many other parts of the town stop outside the hotel. Guests should be careful not to travel on buses with the blue sign Express on the front because they do not stop near the hotel. There are spaces to park cars in the hotel drive. Short or long term guests are welcome but long term guests are offered rooms first. Meal times are: breakfast 7 am - 9.30 am; lunch 1 pm - 2pm; dinner 5.30pm - 7 pm. During the week, for those studying or working late, dinner can be requested until 11pm by writing your name on the late list or by telephoning before 7 pm. No animals of any description or fires of any type are allowed, and guests are requested to respect the comfort of others. If you have tapes or CDs, please try to keep the noise level down to a minimum, especially between the hours of 11pm and 8am.
